q.l: She ne're aw Courts, yet Courts could have undone
with untaught Looks, and an unpractis'd Heart;
Her Nets, the mot prepar'd, could never hun,
For Nature pread them in the corn of Art.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for R. Bentley, at the Pot-houe in Ruel-treet, in Covent-Garden. 1693.

div.head: THE Dedicatory Epitle To the Incomparable MARINDA.
div.p: THIS Novel throws it elf at your Feet, and pays you Homage as its Mater's Repreentative:

It has been the product of ome leiure hours, and will I hope do me this econd kindnes, to divert you in the Reading, as it did me in the Making. I need not, as others, give any reaon for the Dedication; ince to be made by me, is ufficient to entitle it yours:

But that is not the only claim it can lay to your Favour; for in decribing the Marinda
of this Novel, I borrow from you, not only her Name, but ome of the chief Beauties I adorn her with:

Though you may imagine he had no mean ones of her own, ince (being but a private Gentlewoman) he could by their help alone make o udden a Conquet over the Heart of a Prince, who had certainly (in o many Courts as he had been in) een very agreeable Faces, et off with the additional Splendor of Quality, yet none of them had that effect over him, which hers gained without thoe advantages. Beides, her true Character uits very well with you:

She was an Innocent Country Virgin, ignorant of the Intrigues and Tricks of the Court Ladies; her Vertue, like yours, untainted and undecayed, needed none of their Artificial Embellihments to guild it over; and that Innocence which appears eminently in both of you, as little wants thee Ladies Artifices to et it off, as you do their Fucus
for your Faces; ince true Innocence is as far beyond Diimulation, as your Colour is beyond all the Paint of the Town; in both of thee you give Nature as ignal a Triumph over Art, as ever he had in any two things whatoever. I wih I could liken you to her in one thing more; that is, That your Servant were of as high Quality as hers; but this wih is made meerly for your ake:
For to me, as you are more precious than a Crown, o is the Title of a Prince inferiour to that Glorious one, of being the

div.head: The PREFACE TO THE Ill-Natur'd READER.
div.p: THe Dutches of Suffolk, entertaining once at her Table the Bloody Bonner, Bihop of London, ate firt by the Duke her Husband, but the Duke removing her thence, he went and ate by the Bihop, aying, That ince he could not it by him he loved bet, he would next him he loved wort:
So dear dogged Reader, from writing an Epitle to her I love bet, like the Dutches, I change and remove to you whom I love wort: for Writers hate none o much as Ill-natured Readers:

Perhaps you'll ask, why then this Epitle to you whom I hate, and not rather to the Good-natured? Why for the ame reaon that the Dutches ate by Bonner, meerly to pas my Jet on you; though another may be given, which is, That ince Prefaces were partly deigned to make the Reader Indulgent and Favourable
to the Book he is going to read, there's no need of a Preface to others, ince the Good-Natured will be kind to it of themelves; but 'tis you, that put us to the trouble of Prefacing. Therefore to indear it the more to you know, that the main Story is true, I heard of a Gentleman who was acquainted with the Irih Princes, and knew all the Intrigue, and having from him o faithful a Relation of it, I made the Scene the very ame where it was tranacted, the time the ame, going on all the way with the Truth, as far as conveniency would permit; I only added ome few Circumtances, and interlined it with two or three other Stories, for variety ake, which is as neceary to the etting off the true Relation, and making it pleaant, epecially to you nice Readers, as Sauces are to the dreing up a Dih of Meat, to provoke the ickly Appetite it is deign'd for. I Printed it for the eae of her whom it was made for; if you like it, much good
may do you; if you will not believe it, you have Liberty of Concience; but whether you believe, or disbelieve, like, or dilike, is indifferent to me, ince in uch a trivial thing as this, I no more fear dicredit by writing a bad one, than I could hope for Fame in writing it well. But I believe you are eager to ee what is in the Book, and therefore I'll detain you no longer.

div.head: Vertue Rewarded; OR, THE IRISH Princes.

div.p: AS that mighty River which overflows Aegypt, and, with its prevailing Torrent, often drowns thoe Provinces, which Nature only deign'd it to water, yet proceeds at firt from uch mean beginnings, that mot Geographers have been unable to trace it to its Spring:

So Loves wifter and more violent Stream has its firt rie from uch mall Channels, uch trifling circumtances, that the Heart it elf can carce perceive its Original; nay very often does not dicern its progres, till it is too trong for it, and o the udden vigour of its Torrent urprizes the unwary Lover, jut as the Zudder Sea, driven with a North-wet Wind, breaks the Diques, and overwhelms the drowzy Hollander, before he
upects any danger. Yet o Natural is Self-conceit, and o Univeral our pretence to Knowledge, that few there are who will be o Modet, as to own themelves wholly Ignorant of any thing which you hall ask them a Reaon for. Hence it is, that, among other things, Love too is undertood by all, and not one but will give his Verdict of it as oon as you ask him:

The States-man will tell you it is caued by want of Ambition; the Merchant for want of Self-Interet; the Souldier for want of Action, and a thirt after Honour; and the Scholar will prove to you, that 'tis gotten by Idlenes:
But it is with this, as with the Philoophers Stone, whoe myterious Nature all gues at, and none know what it is, for it very often breaks all the Rules that are precribed againt it:

Sets upon the States-man at Court, and overcomes his Ambition; eizes on the Merchant in his Counting-Houe, and weighs down his Interet; finds the Scholar in his Study, and teaches him a new Sytem of Philoophy which baffles all the old; wounds the daring Souldier, even when he is clad in Steel, and makes him tamely ubmit to Captivity, in the very midt of his Conquets:

The Story that I am going
to relate will be an excellent proof of this, being an Intance of an extraordinary ort:

It makes Love triumphant at once over two of thee his greatet Enemies, the Noie of War, and the Vanity of Ambition; and hows you a Prince of great Valour, guarded equally by both of thee, could not defend himelf from the Powerful Eyes of a Forreigner, and one as far beneath him in Quality, as Love afterwards placed her above him, when he lay at her Feet imploring her Mercy. When our preent King had fought the Battel at the Boyn, and drove the Routed Enemy into Limerick, he endeavoured to root up the War, by Reducing that obtinate City, that durt hold out alone againt the force of three Kingdoms, united in a Royal Army; he had then amongt his Forreign Troops everal petty Princes, who fought under him; ome as Volunteers, to learn the Art of War under o Great, o Experienced a Mater; ome as Souldiers of Fortune, who thought by their Valour to recommend themelves to his Favour, and obtain by that means ome Important Charge in the Army, the Honour and Profit of which might exalt and maintain them uitable to thoe High
Characters which their Titles deerved. Among the latter ort may be reckon'd the Prince of Sâ€”g, the mallnes of whoe Principality not affording him an Income agreeable to his High Title, and Higher Mind, he was reolved to acquire that Plenty which his Fortune had denied him, and how by his Valour, that he was nothing beholding to her for giving him Titles, but rather that he was unkind, in not giving him as plentiful a Revenue, as uited with the largenes of his Heart, and the vater extent of his Merit. To this intent he came over Sea in a mall Command, if we conider him as a Prince, though in a Pot eminent enough to give him ome occaions of publihing his Valour; 'twas in this Station he was, when our Forces were from all parts drawing together to invet Limerick, in order to which our Prince was to march through Clonmell, a City in the County of Tipperary, cituated in a large Plain near the Sewer, now grown obcure, formerly famous for the great Battel fought jut by it, between two Brothers who were Competitors for the Crown of Mounter; when that famous Iland had five Crowned Heads to Govern its Inhabitants. It was the Chief Street
of this Town our Prince was marching through, on Hore-back, at the Head of his Men, bowing low to both ides, which were fill'd all along with People, who crowded thither to ee thoe Arms which were to ecure them from the Enemies of their Liberty and Religion; when lifting up his Eyes towards the Windows, which were fill'd with the chief Gentry of the City, he epied in one of them a Beauty which fixed his ight, as if he alone were worthy his Attention:

He continued looking that way, and turned not his Eyes off the Window, till the fierynes of his Hore (which could not indure to tand till) had carried him beyond the Houe, and left the delightful Propect behind him; and afterwards he was o wholly taken up with the thoughts of what he had een, that he rode on without regarding which way, till one of his Officers rode up, and told him that his Highnes was pat the Houe which was deigned him for his Lodging:

The P. at this began to recollect himelf, and giving Orders concerning the good Behaviour of his Souldiers, gave them leave to repair to their everal Quarters, whilt he by the Head Officers was Conducted to his; after ome Ceremonies
pat they repaired to their ret, and left the Prince at liberty to take as much of his, as the inquietude of his Thoughts would permit him. He found himelf tired with Travelling, and deirous of ret, yet incapable of taking any:
He found his Thoughts much diorder'd, and went to Bed to ee whether Sleep would compoe them:

His Soul, like the Bodies of thoe that have the Rheumatim, eemed very weary; yet as their Limbs are till uneaie, though on the oftet Beds, o was his Mind; and coveted leep as much as their Limbs do ret, and could as little obtain it. O Love, thou mot dangerous Ditemper of the Soul! mot dangerous becaue we do not perceive Thee, till Thou art too far gone to be cured:

Thou ubtle Enemy! who taket the tronget Hearts, becaue Thou always uet Surprie; and undermining our Reaon, never appearet in the light, till Thou art too far enter'd to be driven out: 'Twas thus, Treacherous Deity, Thou didt overcome our Prince, by attacking him when he leat was aware of Thee; he little feared Hotility in a Town which he enter'd as a Friend; nor did he expect that one, and that of the weaker Sex, hould offer him Violence
at the head of his Battalion. He upected the true Caue o little, that he wonder'd at his own inquietude, and could not imagine what it was that could keep him awake on a oft Bed, who ued to leep o ound in the Camp on a hard Quilt, and often on the Ground:
However, awake he lay all night, and did not once cloe his Eyes, till day-light hone in at his Window:

At the Sun's firt appearance he got up, quite weary of his Bed, where he had the wort Nights ret he ever took in his Life; for though he had indured the hardhip of many a cold night in Winter Camps; yet they all eemed eaie and pleaant, in comparion of this one Night's Fatigue; for all the thoughts in thoe Camps of Blood and War, the dread of a neighbouring Enemy, and the next day's Battel, were not o troubleome to his Repoe, as thoe of his coming into this Town:

The whole Scene of his entrance intruded into his Thoughts; the Noie and Hurry of the People was till in his Ears; and the Window, and the Charming Spectator that looked out of it, eemed till before his Eyes:

Though he carce mitruted that it was gone o far with him, as to be in Love; yet he was very
deirous to come in Company with that beautiful-Stranger, who had been o much in his Thoughts, and to atisfie himelf whether he was really o Lovely, as he appeared at a ditance:

But neither knowing her Name, nor the place where he lived, he imagined that nothing but accident could bring him to a econd ight of her; but as he was muing upon the difficulty of finding her out, Celadon, the Gentleman of his Hore, came to bid him Good-morrow, and acquainted him, That two or three great Officers were below, waiting for admittance to peak with him:
The Prince, who was glad of any thing that might be an amuement to his troubled Mind, ent for them up, and received them with a great deal of Civility:

After the firt Complements, the Prince told them, He had Orders to await the King's coming to the Town; and after ome dicoure of the Progres of Affairs in general, they began to talk of the pleaure of Company, and how they hould pend thoe few days which they were to pas in the Town:

One propoed Training the Souldiers, another the Tavern, and the third a Conort of Muick; and when every one had pat their Votes, the Prince bad Celadon give
his:

This Celadon was a young brisk Englih Cavalier, of a mall Stature, but a Soul ufficiently Great, and which didain'd to think that the littlenes of his Body made him inferior to any one, either in open Valour in the Field, or the management of an Intrigue at home:
And certainly never was any ones Humour more equally divided, between Love and War, than his:

He was an exact Volunteer in both, and as he would hazard his Peron any time, and fight for him that would give him the bet Promotion, o was he no les a Souldier of Fortune in Love than War; would change his ide often, offer his Service to every Lady that would accept of it, and till was mot hers, who was readiet to reward him:

He was the Younger Brother of a good Family; and having gone into Forreign Camps for a Livelihood, he had by his Courage, Wit, and Good Fortune, raied himelf o high into the Prince's favour, as to be made his Gentleman of Hore; he being to peak in his turn, told the Prince, That ince they had left him a deciding Vote, he was for trying each of them by turns; and if they would begin with the Muick firt, he would add to it one of his own
mot delighting Divertiements, the Company of Women; and to that purpoe, if the Prince pleaed to be that Night at the Ball, he would take care to invite all the young Gentry of the Town to it:

The Prince told him he was the ame he always thought him; that Celadon that took Love to be as important an Affair of Life, as either Eating or Drinking, and accordingly provided for it as carefully; this raillery brought on other dicoure, which lated while Celadon went to make preparations for the Ball; at lat he came back and told them that all things were ready, and the Company invited. On one ide of the Town tood a large Country Houe, which though not built after the Dorick Order, or the exacter neatnes of Courtly Lodgings, yet its largenes gave liberty to gues at the Magnificence and Hopitality of the Owner:

It belonged to the Great Moracho, famous all over the Kingdom for his Riches, particularly in his flocks of Sheep, as numerous as thoe of the mighty Scythian, whoe Son was the Terror of the World; or that Rich Man of the Eat, whom the Turkih Chronicles make Steward to Alexander the Great:

All his
Ground, far and near, was thick covered with his fleecy Wealth:

You would hare thought by their bleatings that you were in Arcadia, and Shepherdim coming in fahion again: 'Twas this Houe which was pitched upon for the Ball; and what place o fit for Dancing and innocent Mirth, as a pacious Hall, whoe Building, Size, and Furniture, altogether rutical, imprinted uch lively Idea's of Country Freedom, and Country Innocence:

Hither Celadon conducted our Prince and his Martial Company; their Muick was as good as the Town could afford, and their Reception uitable to the Riches and Hopitality of him that entertain'd them. The Prince, who went thither, rather to hun his former thoughts, than out of any inclination to the Company, or the Dancing, at by, a Looker-on:

Some of the Officers who were not o eriouly bent, took out thoe whoe Face, Meen, or Shape pleaed them the bet, and in their everal Dances either hewed their Skill, or at leat pleaed themelves with the conceit that they did o. Celadon, who always employed uch a time as this well, was not idle now; but gazed on one, talked to another bowed to the third, and left
none of the Ladies unregarded; and as a cunning Hound, when he comes among a Herd of Deer, ingles out the bet, and never changes Scent, till he runs him down, o our skillful Hunter, who knew all the Mazes, Turnings, and Doublings in the coure of Love, ranged through all the Company of the fairer Sex, till he lighted on the handomet. He would not leave her, till he had prevailed with her to be his Partner in a Country Dance; and tho' till he was drawn out few oberved her, becaue either Chance, or her own Modety had placed her in a dark part of the Room, yet when he came into the light, he alone drew the admiration of all the Men, as he did the envy of the Women:

Her face was oval and omewhat thin, as if grief had but newly left it, yet her looks were as chearful, as if it had not left the leat impreion on her mind; ome igns of the Small-pox were jut perceivable, yet they and her thinnes, intead of leening, erved rather to increae the repute of her Beauty, while they hew'd how it had triumphed over thoe two great detroyers of the handomet Faces:

Her Forehead was high and mooth, as if no Frown had ever deformed it to a wrinkle;
and as much beyond the whitenes of the ret of her Sex, as theirs is beyond the browner Complexion of ours; her Neck, and all the parts of her Face were equally Snowy, except her Cheeks; but they, as if they received their colour from the Rays which her Eyes darted down on them, were of uch a lively Carnation, as if that and the ret of her Face were at a trife, which of thoe two Colours were the bet. Her Eyes were of the ame azure of the clearet Summer Skyes, and, like them too, o hining, that it would dazle you to look on them, and her Brows, which grew over them in an exact Arch, were inclining to a light colour, as if they got it from the brightnes of thoe Beams which hone from beneath them. Her Stature was neither o low as that Sex uually is, nor o till as to eem too maculine; her Shape was curiouly lender, and all her Limbs after a feminine delicacy, but he had withall a Deportment o Great and o Majetick, that the comelines of the tronger Sex was mixed with the graces of the weaker:

And that the tatelines of her Carriage eemed to command that Love and Adoration, which the weetnes of her Face did invite to. I will
not decribe how he was dret, let thoe Ladies be et off with uch helps, who like Peacocks owe their Price to their Feathers; hers were no part of her Beauty, they were put on for Modety, not for Ornament; and erved her as Clouds do the Sun, to creen her more glorious Beauties from the Eyes of weak Mankind, who would ele be as infallibly ruined by the ight of the one, as by the exceive heat of the other. The Prince, who ate looking on the Dance, no ooner aw her, but he knew her to be the ame whom he had een in the Window, and whom he o much longed to come acquainted with, he was overjoy'd that he had gotten an opportunity he o little expected; he was o eager to peak to her, and o impatient till the Dance was over, that any one who had oberved him might eaily have perceived it:

As oon as the Dance was ended, he call'd to Celadon, and telling him that he could not but be weary, proffered to upply his place: Celadon, with a great deal of ubmiion told him, that he was willing to reign any place to his Highnes, and o ate down:

In the mean time a Tune began, and the Lady waited for her Partner; but when he
aw the Prince come, he bluh'd, and deired his Highnes would pardon her, if he pray'd him to chue another, becaue he was weary:

The Prince would not allow of that excue; but when he Danced everal times wrong, and put the Company out, and was out of Countenance her elf, he thought her bluhing proceeded from her not undertanding the Dance, and o accepted the excue, and ate down with her. Having a mind to dicoure with her, and not having o good a command of the Englih Tongue, he poke to her in French, and asked her, did he undertand him? he anwered him again in the ame Language:
div.q: Sir, I have jut uch a mattering of it as you have of Englih, but your Highnes hows me o wie a Preident, of not venturing to dicoure in a Language which I cannot expres my elf well in, that I ought to follow it, and dare no more peak French to your Highnes, than you will Englih to me.

Madam, aid the Prince, though you peak the French Tongue o prettily, that one does not know which becomes your Mouth better, that, or your own, yet e're a one of them is thrown away on you; for that tempting Face peaks o much of
it elf, that had Nature ty'd up your Tongue, yet your Looks alone have power enough to lead all Mankind atray, and draw them more attractively after you by their Eyes, than the mot perwading Eloquence can by the Ears.

Sir, replyed the Lady, Had your Highnes made thee Compliments to ome celebrated Beauty, cutom would have prepared her an Anwer; but to one that is o unued to them as I am, they come o unexpected, that I mut deit Dicouring, as I did jut now from Dancing, not o much becaue I am weary of it, as becaue I do not know how to go on; and really, with us Country Maids, our Tongues walk like our Feet, and as our Country Dances follow an eaie methodical way, o does our Talk; whilt your Court Wit, like your dances, are o made up of Art in one place, a cunning Jet, or a hard Step in another; your Fancies, like your Feet, do caper o high, and are o nimble, that our plainnes eems ridiculous in both, and yours is o difficult to us, that it gives us no hope of ever arriving to as much as a faint imitation.

Dancing, aid the Prince, was deign'd in imitation of
Courthip, the Ladies flying off from the Man to hew her Coynes; her ometimes coming forward, and ometimes retiring, her incontancy; and their meeting at lat ignifies their Marriage; now if the Fahion be here as 'tis in our. Country, to kis at lat, i'faith, Madam, I'll leave Poets and Dancing-Maters to hew their Skill in Talking and Dancing, and care not how unskillfully I go on in either, o that I may be ure of my reward in the end:

If you go no farther than a bare kis, replyed the Lady miling, few would refue your Highnes that reward, to have the honour of Dancing with you; but if you carry on the Simile o far as to relate to Marriage, your Highnes hould conider, that the port of Courthip, like that of Dancing, is quite gone when it comes to the kis; and no more pleaure remains afterwards to the poor tired Dancers, than that of thinking it over again; for then, as an old aying of ours has it, our dancing days are gone.
div.p:
As he poke thoe words, the Dance ended, and ome of the Company coming up to hearken to their dicoure, the Lady roe from her Seat, and took her leave; the Prince could neither
peruade her to tay, nor to give him leave to wait on her home; then he deired to know where he lived, but he begg'd his Pardon:

The Prince, who was reolved to know her, ent his Page to oberve her, and to take notice where he lodged, and o fell in talk with the other Company, continuing it with one or other, till the latenes of the night broke up the Ball, and ent every one to his everal home; the Prince had not been long at his, e're the Page came and brought him word, that he had houed the Lady in the High-treet, that he lived there with a Gentlewoman who was her Mother-in-law:

The Prince who was o uneaie before, and o deirous to ee her, ince he had that interview he wihed for, began to be more at eae, though more in Love than before, and whereas his thoughts were formerly ditracted everal ways, now they ran all on her; the Ball, the Dancing, and all the ret of the Entertainment was as faintly remembred, as if he had only een them in a Dream; but what he had aid or done, was as freh, as if it were that very moment acting over again:

One while he fancied he aw her Dancing, another, that he
aw with what a grace he pake, and every word of her dicoure was as ready in his memory, as if they were the only ones engraven there; no wonder if thoe who will not give credit to the Stories of Apparitions, ay, the Perons are deluded by the exces of Fear, and the trength of their own Fancies, for the force of imagination is as trong in Love as it is in Fear, and makes the cheated Amourit till think he ees the Fair one, and though he be an hundred mile off, yet her Face, her Ayr, her Meen, and every thing that formerly pleaed his ight, eems till to dance before it:

And as the guilty Concience of the Murderer preents the Fantom of the Murdered to his view, o Lovers are haunted with Spectres too, only the Murderers appear in a dreadful, the Lovers in a pleaing Form. This Night had our Prince everal of thee delightful Viions, which were o intruding, that neither his Reaon could banih them while he was awake, nor Sleep free him from them in his Dreams; as oon as he waked he ent for Celadon, and having ordered him to hut the Door, and it down on his Bed-ide, he pake thus to him.
div.q:
When you went with me to the
Emperour's Court, do you remember how many excellent Beauties we aw there? What variety too, Black, Brown, and Light, yet all fair to Perfection; you may remember how indifferent I was to them all, that I never threw away an hours dicoure on them, unles it were to rally the Pride, the Hypocriie, the Ambition, and the other Vanities which that Sex is given to; and then though I eem'd in Jet, yet I took what I pake to be truth, nor did I think that the low opinion I had of Woman-kind would ever let me hew them any regard beyond bare Complaiance: But I was deceived, for I have in thee two days had a greater alteration in my humour, than I believed my whole life could produce:

By your words, Sir, I hould gues, aid, Celadon, that you are in Love, but the conideration of the place where we are corrects that thought, ince in this Iland there is carce one worthy your high Affections.
I wih you could perwade me to that, reply'd the Prince; but will not you recant your own Opinion, when I recall to your mind the Beautiful Partner you lat Night danced with?

The young Gentlewoman, reply'd he,
had as large a tock of Beauty, as the mot Romantick Lover can either wih or imagine in a Mitres; and indeed, if your Highnes has a mind to Intrigue away this Winter that's coming on, I could not wih you a pleaanter than he is likely to make, if her Wit be anwerable to her Beauty:

By what mall tryal I have had of her, anwered the Prince, I believe it falls very little hort of it; and if my Love for her encreaes a little longer, at the ame rate as it has done ince its birth, I fear 'twill out-live more Campaigns with me, than I hall Winters with her:

Why ure, aid Celadon, your Highnes does not deign any more than a Jet in't; for though her Peron deerves a higher tation in the World, yet, ince Fortune has given her neither Quality nor Riches uitable to it, you are not o prodigal a Lover as Mark Anthony was, to quit your Principality, and your Honour beides, for a Mitres:

There's no need of that, aid the Prince; don't lay uch Blockadoes in my way to her; for be it ever o long, or difficult, I will ue both Patience and Diligence to overcome it; for ome way or other I am reolved to
enjoy her; and if you will ait me, I hall not think all that ever I can do for you will make you too large a recompene.

Your Highnes, aid Celadon, never yet gave me an opportunity to hew my diligence in erving you; but if you pleae to tell me how you intend to bring this about, I will follow your directions to the utmot of my Power:

All that I would deire of you at preent, aid the Prince, is to make me an Englih Song, becaue I am not well enough acquainted with the Tongue; make it to the Tune we heard ung to Count Epithalamium, and with your Violin and my Guittar we'll go this Night and Serenade her:
I'll take my leave of you now, aid Celadon, and in the Afternoon I'll wait on you with the Song.
div.p:
Celadon fail'd not his promie, but came in the Evening, and at drinking with the Prince till Mid-night, and then they allied out, to go to the place where they meant to Serenade, taking the Prince's Page with them, both to carry their Intruments, and hew them the Houe. When they were come under the Window, they play'd a while in Conort, till they thought they had awaken'd thoe of the Houe, and
then the Prince bad Celadon give over, and etting his Guittar to anwer his Voice, with a paionate Air he ang this Song,

q.l: WHy hould my fair Enchantres leep,
And yet not dream at all of thoe,
Whom Love of her in torment keep,
And hinders from the leat repoe:
She has kindled fires in my breat,
And robs her Lover of that ret,
Which he her elf does take.

div.p:
When he had Sung thus far he heard the Caement open, and one whiper out of it: Who are you that ditrut your own Peron and Wit o much, that you make your Court by Muick, to help out the one; and chue Mid-night for the time to pay your viits in, that Darknes may conceal the defects of the other? The Prince (becaue 'twas a Woman's Voice, and becaue he would willingly have it o) concluded that it was his Mitres, and therefore anwered her: Thoe, Madam, who have uch Beauty as yours to plead with, ought in their own defence to come in the dark, becaue in the light, the ight of you would take up o
much of their thoughts; that when they have mot need of them, to expres the greatnes of their paion, they'd then be at the greatet los what to ay: You little think how much you are in the right (aid he) for could you ee me 'twould poil your Complementing; for there's nothing o much a bugbear to Wit as an ugly Face: Saying this he clapt to the Window, and nothing which the Prince could afterwards ay gain'd any return. He, thinking his Sport over for that Night, looked about for Celadon, but no Celadon to be found, nor could the Page give any tydings of him:

The Prince thought he might be gone home before him, and therefore followed him, in expectation to know how he came to leave him, and to tell him of his Dicoure with the Lady. Here perhaps the Reader may charge Celadon with Incivility, in running home before the Prince, when he had promied to keep him company; but let the haty Cenurer have as much patience as the Prince himelf, who did not expect to ee Celadon, till he got to his Lodging, and when he came there, was as far to eek for him as ever; but the next morning, the firt who came into his Chamber was Celadon, his Complexion was
wan, and looked as if he was much out of order:

The Prince, who gueed he had been upon an Amour, asked him, what made him look o ill.
After having begg'd your Highnes's Pardon, aid he, for my rudenes in leaving you, I'll tell uch an accident which befell me ince, that your Highnes will think a ufficient punihment for it:
While you were Singing, I aw at a little ditance omething, which, by the whitenes, I gueed to be either a Ghot, or a Woman, and as I am not afraid of either, my Curioity prompted me to ee which it was, I walked that way, and found it to be, not a Ghot, but which was wore, a Shee-Devil in a Night-rail, by which I concluded it to be of that Sex which I had mot inclination to keep company with at that time of Night; the place too eemed to favour the Temptation, being an old Abby, where there was no body nigh to interrupt us:
When I came near her, he broke ilence firt, and aid, O Lord, Sir, you have taid very long, I have been waiting for you this hour: Tho' at firt, by her tanding there, I thought her Common, yet thee words made me take her for ome Lover who had
made an Aignation; I was reolved to peronate him whom the meeting was deigned for; and let he hould know my Voice, I anwer'd in a low tone, that buines hinder'd me, but I would oon make amends for my abence: Jut as he poke this lat word, be runs to the Chamber-door, and having eized a Maid of the Houe, he hall'd her in, crying out, This is the Jilt that play'd me the trick, but I'll be revenged on her: The Maid half dead with fear, could ay nothing for her elf, but cry'd to the Prince for help; he eeing her gentilely dret, and thinking 'twas his Landlord's Daughter, interpoed his Authority, and ordering the Door to be hut, commanded Celadon to be calmer, till he enquired into the matter, and asked the Stranger whether he knew what was the reaon of his Anger:

The Maid deiring that his Highnes would hear her, and then judge between them, began thus:
I perceive by this Gentleman's Anger, that he has been groly abued; that I have been in ome ort the caue, I am orry; but to hew you I am a very innocent one, I'll give you a relation of ome paages of my life, which
though publickly known, yet never hould have been told you by me, were it not on uch an important account as this, the allaying this Gentleman's rage againt me, and the hindering him from noiing any thing abroad, which might be to the prejudice of my Reputation:
My Father is a Country Gentleman, decended from a good Family, but his Ancetors were o improvident, as to pend mot of their Etate, and leave him but a mall remainder to maintain a great many Children:
I am the younget of all, the Favourite both of Father and Mother, whoe greatet care has been to Match me o, that they may live to ee me happy. I had choice enough; for thee three or four years I have had little ret from Suitors, who from all parts of the Country ollicited me:
My Fortune, I believe, they did not court me for, becaue I aw everal who had far greater were neglected; People flatter'd me indeed with the title of a Beauty, and Fame, who is mot commonly a great Lyar; did lit my Name among her wonders; whether he was in the wrong or no, I could wih he were, for it has put me to more trouble
than a good Face is worth, to bear with the everal impertinencies of my young Country Servants; though to have een their everal humours would have been as good as a Comedy to me, had I been meerly a Spectator, but I lot the pleaure becaue I was an Actres in it my elf:
Every one of them had a particular behaviour, yet every one omething of the Harlequin in it; and their Courthip was different, according to their diverity of humours:
One had Confidence, and thought that would gain me, and he'd be the mot troubleome, becaue he'd touze me and hale me about, and I had much ado to defend my elf from his rudenes; him I avoided as I would the Devil. Another would think to gain me by his over-civility, and he'd come a great way jut to ask me how I did, and how my Father and Mother did, ask me what a Clock it was, and what time of the Moon, and where I was at Church lat Sunday; and after ome uch wie dicoure, he'd take a kis and be gone; he was my Chip in Porridge, I neither hunn'd his Company, nor cared for it. A third, pufft up with the good ucces of having gotten
his Father's Maid, or Tenant's Daughter with Child, believed the ame Methods would conquer me, and therefore thought to entertain me with immodet dicoure; my Vertue made me deaf to all he could ay, and for my Reputation ake I avoided him. Then a Widower came, a Couen, addreed to me, deiring to be nearer a-kin, and thought to touch my heart, but indeavoured it after o rude a manner, as if he forgot that 'twas a Maid, not a Widow, he was Courting:
But it appeared, for all his long practiing Merchandie, that he did not undertand how to Purchae, for all that he had in the World could not buy my conent to give him mine. A fifth was opinionative of his rutick valour, and he'd aim at conquering his Mitres the ame way as Knights Errant did of old, by quarrelling and beating every one he came near:
But I thought uch an over-boyling Courage, which would till expoe me to fears for him, was fitter for a Bravo, than a Husband. The ixth was my true Country Courtier, who was all Innocence; he had carce Courage enough to keep him from wooning, when he came into my
Company, unles his Spirits had been raied before-hand, by a dram of the Bottle, or a belly full of trong drink; then he'd ay, his Mother ent him to ask me whether I'd have him; and tell me a long tory of his Ground, his Dairy, and his Cattle; I depied this Milkop, and thought it a hard bargain to give my elf in ubjection to the chief Beat, only to be Mitres of the ret. This was my condition, when a young Gentleman, a Stranger, came down into our Country to ome Friends he had there; and no ooner aw me, than he encreaed the number of my Captives, and profeed himelf my Servant, but when he firt old it me, 'twas with all the Rhetorick which an ingenious paion could invent, his Eyes, his Actions, and every geture o gracefully econded his Story, that the Lover's part, which the others acted o ridiculouly, became him o well, as if he were only made for Love. When he paid a viit, if any of the ret chanced to come at the ame time, the Breeding which he brought from Dublin, elevated him o far above them, in his Dicoure, his Carriage, and all he did, that they did look like our
wild Irih to him; but when alone he talked to me of Love, the Muick of his Tongue was o enchanting, I could have taid and liten'd for ever to him. Sir, I will ay no more in his commendation, for methinks Lovers are o much a part of our elves, that their praies look fulome where they come from one another, I will only tell your Highnes that we were but too happy in one another, till Fortune, who is never contantly kind, contrived a way to part us aunder:
But why hould we cure our ill Fortune, or lay the fault on the Devil, when any michance does befall us? Whereas poor Beelzebub is wrong'd, for he could not do us half the michiefs we receive, unles we helped him againt one another, and of all people I think the Envious are his principal Agents, of which this is a remarkable intance:
There lived in the ame Houe with him, one Capella, a tale Maid, of a good Family, but a decayed Fortune, and he, it eems, hearing of our Amour, envied the happines of it:
I can't ay 'twas out of any violent Love to him, for her being pretty far advanced in years, and ickly beides, do make me think her Loving
time was pat, at leat I'm ure it hould have been, for her grey Hairs, her Dwarfihnes, her Sicklines, her Pale Ill-favoured Face, and her want of a Fortune to gild all thee Imperfections, might have hindered her from thinking of Marriage, if he had any Wit to conider them; but he will repent the want of it, when the foolih deire of Intriguing in her old Age, has rendered her ridiculous to all the Gentlemen, and after wating her Youth in Pride and Didain of thoe that more than deerved her, make her take up at lat, for want of a better, with a Ploughman, a Groom, or a Footman. I fear your Highnes will think this a very illnatur'd Character, but I will beg you to conider, that it proceeds from her own deerts, and the reentment an injured Love does uually raie in our Breats, againt thoe who are the chief caues of our unhappines; as certainly he was of mine, for the Nets he often, and in vain, pread for others, were now laid for him:
And becaue he thought the Love of me diverted him; after having with Jeers and Perwaions, Scorn and Flattery, Anger and Kindnes, and all the different ways
he could think on, in vain attempted to hake his Contancy; she was reolved to make me loe him, though he lot him her elf by it; and getting ome of her Relations to repreent me to his, as diadvantageouly as they could, they (let he hould loiter away his Youth in Love, and not purue that Preferment to which his Genius was likely to raie him) called him up to Dublin. I, partly to huh the dicoure which her Malice had raied of us, about the Countrey, partly, becaue it made me melancholly, to ee thoe deerted Shades, where I had formerly been o happy, quitted that place, and choe my Aunt's Houe, where your Highnes is, now, for my retirement. He came to Town, incognito, to ee me, and for fear ome of his Friends hould hear of it, our meetings were always in private. An Abbey hard by (being olitary and free from any company that might diturb us) we pitched upon for our lat nights Aignation:
I was there firt, and this Gentleman coming by, I mitook him for the other:
He'll own himelf that he began to be too familiar, and let he hould offer me violence at that time
of night, when no body was near to help me, I was driven to this hift to get rid of him:
I aw which way his nature inclined him, and thence concluded there was no way to deliver my elf, but by putting him in hopes of ome better Intrigue; I therefore told him, I would not detain him from my Mitrees's Embraces, who had been waiting for him this long while (pretending I mitook him for ome other Gentleman) and o drew him from thence, deigning at the firt Houe I aw any up, to pretend he was there, and o leave him:
I durt not come home with him, let the vexation of finding himelf deceiv'd, hould make him raie the Houe, and to come home with an Officer at that time of Night, would have ruined me in my Aunt's good opinion. It fell out as well as I could wih, for an Ale-houe was open, and deiring him to go and enquire for her there, I bad him good night, and came home as fat as my fear could carry me:
What became of him after I know not, only deire that he would impute it to his own Curioity, if he has uffered; and that both your Highnes and he will be o honourable,
as to keep what I have related from others Ears, as trictly as I would have kept it from yours, had I not been contrained to reveal it in jutification of mine Honour. The Prince, who had litened with delight to the Love-tory, it jumping o well with the humour he was then in, told the young Gentlewoman, that he had a great repect for her, as he was a Gentlewoman, and o near a Relation of his Landladies, but more, as he was Beautiful, Vertuous, and a Lover, and wihed her a great deal of Succes. Celadon begg'd a thouand pardons for the rudenes his Ignorance had betray'd him to; and that he might be the more inclined to pardon him, he deired her to tay, and hear the unlucky adventure he had after he left him. The Prince deired her to eat her elf, and Celadon with half a mile, and a bluh together, thus continued his Story. You may remember, Madam, that I promied you to make amends for my long tay, and went about to be as good as my word, had not your Vertue and Cunning retrained me more than my own:

And tho' I have all along aid that no Woman could reit Opportunity and Importunity, yet now I renounce
my Error, and could my elf become a Proelyte to Chatity, were I o happy as the Gentleman you waited for, I mean, in having o Fair, o Vertuous a Mitres, to regulate my wandering deires, and confine them to her elf; as it is, your example, and lat nights trick put upon me, have half Converted me:

I will own to you, that I did really think you had mitaken me for another; I was big with hopes of the Blis you promied to conduct me to; and 'twas either your widom, or good luck, not to go into the light with me; I aw indeed o much of you, as to know you again by your Cloaths; but had I een that alluring Face, your feigned Mitres had not erved your turn; I did not, becaue I avoided your eeing mine, for fear you hould dicover me to be the wrong Peron:

For the ame reaon, I was loath to ask your Mitres's Name, and choe rather to enquire for her at a venture, concluding, that if I once came into her Company, the fear of my dicovering her Amour would over-awe her, and make her as kind to me, as if I were the Spark that he waited for:

Beides, the heat of my Inclination puhed me forward at a venture, whether I ucceeded
or no:
I went therefore into the Houe, and asked a Boy at the Bar, whether there was ever a Gentlewoman there who expected me:

The Boy asked me what her Name was: What's that to you, aid I? Is there ever a Gentlewoman in the Houe? The Boy, who undertood his Trade, gueed what I meant; hewed me a Room, and ent in a Woman to me:

Her colour was very good, for I believe he was Painted, her Look was brisk, and her Garb gentile enough; for my Garb being pretty rich, they thought to make a good Prize of me, and therefore ent me, I uppoe, the choicet Girl in the Houe. I took her to be the ditreed Wife of ome old Man, who had married her to make her his Nure, and therefore told her it belong'd to my Profeion to help the ditreed. She told me he thought, by my Tone and Whiskers that I was an Out-landih Man; asked me how long I had been in Town, and whether I was a meer tranger to that place; pretending as if he was afraid of my coming to the knowledge of whoe Wife he was. I told her I was an Englih-man, had been beyond Sea everal years; that I came to Town but two or three days ago, with the Prince's Troops, and
hould uddenly be marching to Limerick, and that therefore he hould make the better ue of me while I taid, and never fear a dicovery afterwards; by this he gueed I hould never be able to find the Houe again; and that embolden'd them to deal as they did with me; he eemed to be o cautious, out of a fear of her Honour; when therefore he had gotten as much knowledge of my being a Stranger, as atisfied her fears, he began to be more familiar with me, and, out of a particular piece of kindnes, would needs end out for a Bottle of Sack for me, aying, he would drink a health to the good man at home; we both laugh'd at the conceit; I, how little he thought of his Horns, and he to think how little I upected the Trick he was going to play me:

The Wine he would needs drink mull'd, and, ordering it her elf, he infued either Opiate, or ome uch Soporiferous draught; we had no ooner drank it off, than he conented to go to Bed, aying, that her Husband was out of Town, and the Houe belonging to a Friend of hers, no body was likely to trouble our pleaures:

Becaue I upected nothing, I never minded how little he drank; and you know, Madam,
we uually indulge Women their liberty in drinking, therefore very likely he drank les, and o it might have les operation upon her; it worked o on me, that I did not wake till late in the morning, and when I firt opened my Eyes, I found my elf in the innermot part of the Abby, which I aw you at lat Night; I was laid on a Tombtone, by the ide of a great Marble Statue (the Effigies of ome Great Peron formerly buried there) I wonder'd to find that my Bed and Bedfellow had both uffered uch a Niobetick alteration, that they who were o oft and warm lat Night, were become o hard and cold by Morning; but I wonder'd more at my elf, when I found no Cloaths, but an old Francican Habit on me, I began to think of Plato's tranmigration, and that I had died an Officer, and for my lewdnes in my former body, was doom'd now to be an abtinent Francican: But I had not much time to think, for by this time, a zealous Neighbour that had een me aleep, thought he would catch the Frier napping, and brought a Contable for me; the Man of Authority order'd me immediately to appear before a Jutice of Peace. I was conducted
in State through the Streets, at the head of a Party, more numerous than your Highnes's body of Souldiers; they huzza'd all the way, as if the King were going by; and methought I went in great Pomp, only my Triumph was after the Roman fahion, with the Lictor behind me, who every now and then threat'ned me with Bridewell, the Stocks, and the Gibbet:
In this manner I marched near half a mile to the Jutice's, barefooted all the way, which I think of it elf was ufficient pennance for my lat nights Debauch:

The Jutice asked me a great many impertinent quetions; as how I durt appear there in that Habit? and why I did not go after the French to Limerick? I aw it bet to confes what I was, and told him all the latter part of my adventure, how that the People of the Houe knowing, by my own confeion, that I was a Stranger, and not likely to find the Houe again, had robb'd me of all my Cloaths at Mid-night, and left me there in an old Habit, which ome poor Holy Brother had formerly given them as the return of a kindnes:

The Jutice would not believe but this was a Jeuitical evaion of mine, and therefore bad me, if I was a Souldier, end for ome body that I
was acquainted with; I named two or three Officers of my Acquaintance, and the Jutice ent one for them, they were found in a Tavern with a great deal of other Company, and the fellow delivering his Meage publickly, they all came to ee the Novice in his Habit; their Tetimony releaed me, and I was fain to borrow ome Cloaths to go home in, having lot a very good Suit of my own, and mot part of the ready Money I have in the World, and have got nothing for it, but the name of Celadon the Francican, which will tick by me as long as I live:

Your Highnes may ee now the caue of my palenes, is the potion I drank, and the cold Lodging I had, which if it had not happen'd at uch a hot time of the year, would have made me dye in a more Religious Habit than ever I lived in. You, Madam, if you have any uch thing as pity in you, will excue me, and think that the hame, the los, and the cold I uffered might be ufficient caue to make me angry with you, whilt I thought you one of the Accomplices. The fair Stranger, with a pitying mile, told him, That he was orry he had uffered o much by her means, and aid, that to hew he did
no way conent to it, he would end one who hould hew him the Houe; and if he would carry a Contable with him, he might recover all his things again. The Prince, who had laughed till he was weary, bad Celadon call up the Centry, him he ent for a File of Musqueteers, and deiring the beautiful Stranger to end a Guide with them to the Houe, ent Celadon with them. The young Gentlewoman, bidding the Prince good morrow, went to her Uncle and Aunt to give them ome hare of the Laughter, and ordering one of the Servants to go with the Souldiers to the Houe, there Celadon found his lat nights Mitres, and having recovered his Cloaths and his Watch, he ent for the ame Contable, who had conducted him o carefully to the Jutice's, and leaving his Mitres, and her fellow Nuns to the publick Jutice, he came back to the Prince very well atisfied that he had come off o well, and bought his experience o cheap. Though the oddnes of Celadon's adventure did for ome time employ the Prince's mind, yet at lat, by a long chain of thought, he returned to the accutomed Subject his Mitres:

For as the Jack of the Lanthorn is aid to lead
the benighted Country-man about, and makes him tread many a weary tep in fruitles rounds, yet leaves him near the ame place where it found him at firt; o Love's deluding fire, after enticing the blinded mind through many retles thoughts, brings it about again to its beloved Idea, that enchanting circle it can never leave; 'twas this bewitching Paion which brought our Prince from Celadon's adventure to the fair Strangers, and from hers to his own; and when he call'd to mind the Story of her Lover, and his ucces over her heart, he pleaed himelf with hopes of the like Fortune in his own Amour, and thought it very probable, that a Prince, who had everal advantages over one of a private Fortune, might expect the ame ucces, and not fear the like diappointment, ince he had no power to over-awe, or check his Love, or Relations to controul it. Finding a great deal of diverion in this melancholly entertainment, he reolved on a walk, as well to take the Air, as to prevent the engaging himelf in any Company, which might come to eek him at his Lodgings; when he had walked about half a mile, he found himelf on the top of a Hill,
whence after having looked a while on the adjacent Town, and with a curious Eye earched out that part of it, which his admired Beauty made happy with her preence, he laid him down under the hade of two or three large Trees, whoe preading Boughs nature had woven o cloe together, that neither the heat of the Sun, nor torm of the fiercet Wind could violate the pleaant hade, which was made as a general defence, no les againt the corching of the one, than the nipping of the other; they eemed to have been firt planted there, for the helter of thoe who came thither to drink; for jut by there bubbled up a clear and plentiful Spring, of which, from an ancient Irih Chronicle, let me give you this Story. Cluaneeha, the only Child of Macbuain, King of Munter, was accued of having been too familiar with one of her Father's Courtiers; the Fact was atteted upon Oath by two Gentlemen that waited on the King's Peron, and to confirm it, the Princes her elf had uch a welling in her, that few doubted but their Witnes was true, and would oon be proved by her being brought to Bed:

Her Father, being old and ickly, was deired, for
the prevention of Civil Wars after his Death, to nominate a Succeour:

The People hewed their unanimous conent to confer the Crown on her Uncle, becaue they would not have a Strumpet for their Sovereign; o the old King was perwaded to proclaim his Brother Heir Apparent, and condemn his Daughter to a Cloiter:

The Courtier fled beyond Sea, and went a Pilgrimage to the Saint at Ponanie; the very night that he arrived there, one appeared to the Mother Abbes, in the form of a Nun glorified, and told her, that he was Edith, Daughter formerly to Kingâ€” but now in happines; that he loved Chatity and Innocence while he was on Earth, and therefore defended it till; that he was contrained to leave the eat of Blis to protect Vertue, injured in the Peron of Cluaneeha; that the Perons who wore againt her were uborn'd; that the welling of her Belly was but a Dieae; and that if he and the witnees would go and drink of a Well, which prung out of a Hill near Clonmell, there he would convince all the Spectators, that what he now told her was true:

The Abbes told this the next day to the King's Confeor, and he told
it the King; the King ordered one who was Confeor to the two Witnees, to enjoin them, for their next pennance, to drink no other Liquor, but the Water of this Well, for a Week together; they obey'd him, but it was their lat, for it made them well as if they were poioned; in the mean time the Mother Abbes came down thither with her Royal Novice. She charged them with the Perjury, and they confeed publickly, that the King's Brother, taking the advantage of that welling, which he thought was but a Tympany, uborned them to wear againt her Chatity, expecting that either it would kill her, or at leat it might deceive the People o long till the King was dead, and he in poeion of the Crown:

A certain Citizen of Clonmell, who came among the ret to ee them dying, and heard the Confeion, admiring the trange virtue of the Water, went immediately home to his Wife, and telling her that he was upitious of her Honety, and deired that, to atisfie his Jealouie, he would drink a draught of Water, and wih it might be her lat, if he were unfaithful:

She not having yet heard of the others punihment, and willing to clear her elf,
drank of it as he deired, but well'd with it as the others did, and dyed oon after in great torment. When the Well had grown famous by the exemplary deaths of the Perjured Witnees, and the Adulterate Citizen, the Princes declared he would drink of it too; and that the clearing of her elf might be as publick as her accuation was, he ent up to the King, who was then at Cork, to deire that her Uncle himelf might be preent when he drank, to witnes her innocence; he excued himelf, and would not go, but a great many of the Court coming thither to ee the Princes clear her elf, he went in olemn Proceion barefoot, from the City to the Well; and taking up a glas full of the Water, he proteted her Innocence, and uing the ame imprecation with the others, if he did not peak the truth, drank it off; but intead of working the ame effect on her, it in a little time cured her of the Dieae he had, recovered her Health, and with it brought her o much Beauty, that all the neighbouring Princes were Rivals for her:

She had deign'd to build a Nunnery by that Well, but her Father dying left her the cares of a Crown, which diverted her from it:
But the Well was long after reverenced, and for the quality it had of dicovering Unchatity, it was much reorted to; for the Inhabitants of Ireland (how barbarous oever the partial Chronicles of other Nation report 'em) were too nice in Amour to take a polluted Wife to their Bed, as long as this Well would hew them which was a chat one; but the wickednes of after times grew too guilty to bear with uch Tryals; thence by difue this Well lot its Fame, and perhaps its Vertue. And now I will no longer tell uch Tales, but leave the uncertain Lover to take his Lot as it comes. Pretty near this Well the Prince lay down, and being pleaed with the murmuring of its Stream running down a decent of the Hill, that, and his want of Sleep the night before, tempted him to take it now; Morpheus was ready at his call, and waving his Leaden Rod over him, lull'd all his Senes, till a greater power than he recued him from leep, to Charm him in a more prevailing manner; for as he waked he heard one hemm, and found it was in order to Sing, for preently the unknown, with a ravihing Air, began this Song.

l.hi: YIeld, Souldier, yield, give up your Sword,
Yield on all conquering Beauty's word,
And take what quarter he'll afford,
And you hall wear the lighter Chain.
Why do you put uch trut in Art?
In vain, fond Wretch, you Arm,
And think Steel proof 'gaint Beauty's dart,
Which will, like light'ning, pierce you Heart,
yet do your Coat of Mail no harm.

div.p: The excellency of the Voice, and the uitablenes of the Sence to his own condition, made him lye till to hearken to her that Sung it, and litening very attentively, he over-heard another Voice, which breaking ilence began thus. I thank you, dear Marinda, for the Song, I like the Tune you have put to it, and either that, and the weetnes of your Voice, do make me partial, or ele the Song is very good:

I like the Authority it carries with it, for I am uually well pleaed when I hear thoe Songs, which attribute o much power to our Sex; but prethee tell me, why is a Souldier the aim of it? when I have heard you ay, that a Souldier hould be your lat choice,
becaue they are always abroad, and therefore very eldom enjoy'd after Marriage, and while they are Suitors their Pride makes them the mot troubleome, and the mot incontant of any; when they pay a viit, if there be a Glas in the Room, they look more on themelves, than on her they came to ee, and as often as they look on their Scarf and Feather, their Vanity puffs them up o, that if we yield not immediately, they Swear and Cure, and o fall off, taking it as an unpardonable affront that we don't admire them at firt ight; and when they are beloved, their Self-conceit makes them place it to the account of their own Merits, and o they value our Love the les, becaue they think it their due; nay, and are not contented with a ingle Conquet, be it ever o fine a one, and as they do not fight for Malice, o neither do they court for Love, but out of the pure vainglory of Conquering; and take as much Pride in having abundance of Mitrees, as abundance of Soldiers to follow them. You oberve right (aid he who was called Marinda) I'le grant to you, that for thee coniderations, they are both the wort of Servants, and wort
of Husbands, and yet in a brave Souldier there is omething o Noble, I mean in, his not fearing dangers, and his patient endurance of all manner of hardhips, that were it not for the aforemention'd inconveniencies of Abence, Pride, and Incontancy, I hould have a greater value for uch a one, than ever I yet had for any other Employment:

Nay, now Marinda (reply'd the other) you make good the Character which our Sex bears among the Men, of being incontant as the Wind; for 'twas but two or three days ago you were of a clear contrary Opinion, and you knew the ame qualities of Courage and Hardines to be then in a Souldier which you do now, and therefore they are no jut reaons why you hould alter your mind; they make ome hew of being Arguments indeed, but I have oberved that Wits, when they alter their Opinions, whether it be in point of Religion, Allegiance, or any thing ele, never want omething to ay in their own defence:

Well, ince you are o deirous (aid Marinda) to know the caue of this alteration of humour in me, I'll tell it you; though in doing o, I rather follow the dictates of Friendhip than Dicretion, and prove
kinder to you than to my elf, in telling you that which I am almot ahamed to think of. You know that about three or four days ago a Party of Foreigners made their entrance into this Town, with the Prince of Sâ€”g at the head of them, Curioity made me open my Window to ee them pas by, either the deire of looking about him, or the pride of being gazed at, made the Prince ride lower by that place than ordinary, and he had his deign, for I looked as tedfatly on him, as if he had been the only Pageant there; and tho', without doubt, there were everal Officers very brave and fine; yet the eeing him firt had o prejudiced me in favour of him, that I could not think the ret worth the looking on; all the ret of that day I could not forbear thinking of him, fancying I aw with what a Grace he at his Hore, how tately he look'd, o far beyond the ret of his Souldiers, as if nature, as well as Fortune, had marked him out for a Prince and ditinguihed him from the ret, as much by his peron, as by his power; and as the thoughts of the day have an effect upon thoe at night, o I believe thee were the caue of my being diturbed in my Bed with this Dream.
The Prince, methought, in my abence, had hidden himelf in my Bed-chamber, and, when I came in, tarted out upon me:

He had on one ide of him a little wing'd Archer, who bent his Bow, and aimed at me everal times; but jut by me there tarted up a great Gigantick form, with no other Arms but a Shield, and he, methought, till interpoed that, and with it kept off the Arrows of the other; at length, methought, the Prince poke omething which tempted my Defender over to his ide, and left me to the Mercy of the young Archer, who hot me through and through; and at the ame intant the Prince came and catched me in his Arms, and told me I was his Prioner, at which, methought, I wooned away with a pleaing pain, and at the fright of it I awaked. People ay Dreams are ignificant, if they are, tell me what you think is the meaning of this? Why truly, (aid the other) any one who hould hear you tell this, might gues, without any great skill in Fortune-telling, that you are in Love:

If (aid Marinda) I did think a little the day before upon the Prince, which might have been the caue (as you ay) of this Dream, yet thoe thoughts were too
lightly grounded to be of any long continuance, and I was in hopes in a day or two to have clearly rooted them out; and the next Afternoon one of my Acquaintance came to deire my Company to a Ball, I was ready enough to accept of the proffer, becaue I imagined that the Muick and the Company would cure me of my thoughtfulnes; but (as my ill Fate would have it) it was clear contrary; for whom hould I meet at the Ball but the Prince; you were there, and aw how I was clearly put out of my Dance, with the confuion his preence put me in:

He ate down with me, and made me ome few Compliments, which tho', perhaps, were coveted by ome of the Company, yet had thoe Ladies een my inide, as well as they did my outide, they would rather have pitied, than envied me; 'twas he that ung under my Window lat night, and though you mitook him for your Servant, yet I knew his deluding Voice too well:

His words were o pathetical, and the Tune o moving, that though he had skill enough at the Guittar, which he plaid on, yet that kept not time with his Voice truer than my Pule and Heart did. Have a care Marinda (aid the other) that you do
not engage too far with one who is o much above you; 'tis not afe Intriguing with Perons of his Quality; Inferiour Lovers may be jeted with as long as we pleae, and thrown off at will, but uch as he eldom leave us without carrying away our Vertue, or at leat our Reputation:

And you will too late cure your own Charms when they have expoed you to be ruined (like a young Conjurer) by raiing a Spirit which you are not able to lay. I fear (reply'd Marinda) he has py'd omething in my behaviour that (he fancied) favoured him, as Mens conceitednes makes them too apt to dicover uch things; I am orry for it, if I did dicover any weaknes in my elf, that hould encourage him to uch an attempt:

I am ure my Tongue never dropt the leat word in his favour; and if my tell-tale Eyes, or my Countenance has betray'd me, I'll disfigure this Countenance, and tear out thee Eyes, rather than they hall invite, or ait any enterprize, to the prejudice of my Vertue. Now though I have told the Reader the dicoure thee Ladies had in private, yet let him not expect that I hall tell him the Prince's thoughts upon it; that I hould not be able to do,
though I had been in his heart, for they were o different, that he carce knew what to make of them himelf:
He certainly had need of a great preence of mind, to reolve upon uch a udden what to do, whether to dicover himelf, or no:

If he did, he aw ome probability that the Lady might be kinder, when he knew that he had heard her confeing a Love for him; if he did not interrupt them, he thought he might hear more; but while he was in this irreolution he chanced to Sneeze, at which the Ladies aroe from the eat which they were on by the Well, and walked away, very likely becaue they found ome body was nearer than they had imagined, and were afraid of being over-heard in their dicoure:

The Prince lay a while muing on what he had heard, and then went home; he related it all to Celadon, and asked his advice what ue he hould make of it: Celadon told him it was not the afet way to extort a confeion of Love from her, by letting her know he had over-heard her, becaue that might make her angry at his hearkening, and uch a dicovery might be too violent for a Maiden Modety, and o nice a one as hers eemed
to be; he deired him rather to continue his Addrees, and o bring her by degrees to a voluntary ubmiion; that this was the more natural and the urer way; that twice or thrice more being in her Company would enure his Conquet over her; and what need was there to hazard her dipleaure, by forcing her to confes he loved him, when he was well enough atisfied of it already? The Prince conented to this, and contrived this way to ee her; he knew the Town was o full of Souldiers, that every Houe had ome of them in it, he thought hers quartered ome Officers, and enquiring out who they were, he told Celadon that he would go and ee them at their Lodgings:

That Evening they went together to the Houe, and a Maid hewing them into the Parlour, they found there Marinda and two Strangers, one of which the Prince knew to be the ame he had een at the Well with her; they would have left the Room when they aw the Prince come in, but he was too well skill'd in War to let a weak Enemy retreat, he had not ought her out to let her go o eaily; he was thinking of ome hift to put off the Officers, whom the Maid was gone to call, when to his
great atisfaction he brought him word, they were not at home:

He aid, that having o pleaing Company, he could very well tay till they came in, and itting down, he made a ign to Celadon to entertain the Strangers, to give him the greater freedom with Marinda, and that he had not long, for the Mother came in:
Then he (as old Women uually do) took up mot of the talk her elf, till the Prince, tired with it, took his leave:

As they walked home, Celadon asked the Prince what he thought of Marinda. I take her, (aid the Prince) to be the mot perfect Innocence that ever was ince the fall of Eve: Her words are o Witty, and yet o modet, her humour o nicely Vertuous, and yet o Civil, that I account the Country Ignorance which is in her, to be beyond all the breeding in the World. I told her that I made an advantagious exchange in getting her Company, by their not being within whom I came to ee; he aid, he was not of the ame opinion, ince if Men in general were as good Company as I, he mut needs blame the unkindnes of Nature, which had made her of o unociable a Sex, that he was neither Wit enough to convere with Men, nor would the
Rules of Vertue give a Maid that liberty, if he were otherwie qualified for it:

I told her that all who knew her but o much as I did, mut needs contradict her, in that Nature had given her Wit as well as Beauty; that the one was made to delight the Ears of Men, the other their Eyes; and as without always cloetting her elf up, he could not bar us from the lat, o neither, without great injutice, could he deprive us of the one half of our happines, by tying her elf up to an obtinate ilence, meerly to deprive us of the other. She miled, and aid, he had not power enough over her elf, to oberve that ilence which a Maid ought; but that ince Men, by their ininuating dicoure, drew words from her which he hould keep in, he would hun the Company of that deluding Sex, and o keep her elf from yielding o much to them, by not coming within reach of the temptation:

She bluhed as he poke thee words, and I might have gained ground mightily on her yielding heart, if the old Gentlewoman had not unfortunately come in to her recue. The prince pleaed himelf much with the thoughts of his Conquet, but he knew not what a tubborn Enemy Vertue
is, and how difficult it would be for him to take any advantage over a Heart, which that maintain'd againt him. Having found o little reitance at his firt viit, he believed Celadon's obervation was true, that two or three more would win her; he went often, under pretence of eeing the Officers, and ometimes met with them, but never with Marinda; once or twice the Servants aid he was abroad, but the lat time he enquired for her, they aid he was ick; he fancied that he had ordered the Servants to deny her, and therefore judged the readiet way to ee her would be by his former Stratagem, a Ball; and that he might not be expected there, he gave out the Evening before, that he was going for Dublin the next day to get Orders from the King:

He rode through the Town that Morning, and her Houe being in the way, he called at the Door, and asked to peak with one of the Officers that lodged there, but to the intent that he might take notice where he was going:

When he was out of ight of the Town, he rode back again to his Lodgings another way, keeping cloe, that no body might know of his return; and when he thought the Ball was at the
highet, he and Celadon went there together; the place where they Danced was the ame where the firt Ball was, the Company almot the ame, only that it wanted the Beautiful Marinda, but in wanting her it wanted all, nothing there was worthy to entertain our Prince, therefore he called to Celadon to go with him home; but Celadon was of another mind, he was not o nice in his choice, to retire himelf from uch variety of good Company, meerly for the abence of one; he was very little pleaed with the capriciounes of the Prince's humour, and would have willingly taid behind, if he had thought it would not dioblige him:

But the Prince being deirous to go, they took leave of the Company, and were going out together, when, at the Door, they were met by a couple of Ladies in a trange Spanih dres; and their Faces, after the mode of that Nation, had long Vails over them: Celadon bobb'd the Prince, and deired him to come back to ee what Masks thoe were, telling him, that under them he might chance to find Marinda; the Prince was in hopes of it too, and made up to them, but found himelf deceived; for peaking to one of them in French, he eemed not
to undertand him, but whipered to the other, and he poke to him in Spanih, asking him whether he was not the Prince of Sâ€”g, Commander of the Forces now in Town? The Prince anwer'd her that he was; but deired her if he could peak any other language to do it, for he undertood very little of that. I peak, Sir, (aid he) a little Englih, and if your Highnes can undertand me better in that, I hall beg the honour of a hearing from you, for I do not know but it may lye in your Highnes power to do me a great kindnes:

What is that kindnes, pretty Petitioner (aid Celadon) for all your excellent counterfeiting (Madam) I fancy you are two of this Town, that pretend ome ober buines with us now, and deign to laugh at us when ye are gone, for being o little curious, as to ee nothing of a Lady but her dres. That you may not think (aid the other Lady in broken Englih) that we are not of this Countrey, we'll dance you a Sarabrand after the Spanih way, and if that will not convince you, I can hew you o ugly a Face, that mine hall be the lat Veil you hall ever deire to look under:

Let us have the Dance (aid Celadon) and if your Air
and Meen be as becoming as your Shape, I hall venture to look in your Faces, for all your threatning. The Company left off Dancing to look at thee two, whoe dres eem'd o extraordinary, and the Prince, who had a mind to ee them Dance, ordered the Muick to play uch a Tune as pleaed them bet, and they with their Catinets acquitted themelves very gracefully, and came off with the commendation of all the Company:

Their Shapes and Carriage being very near alike, Celadon did not know which to like bet of them; he told them that now he mut deire to ee their Faces, that the handomet might take him all to her elf, and free him from the double Captivity he now lay under, of being a Slave to them both; but one of them told him they could not grant it, for he had a boon to the Prince, in the begging of which he mut open uch private paages of her Life, as would make her ahamed to be een by the Man that knew them; but if it e're lay in the Prince's power to grant her it, then he would turn Englih Woman, and throw off her Veil. The Prince aid that was a very plauible excue, and deired Celadon to urge the Strangers no more,
and turning to them, told them, that whomoever that Story concerned, he deired he would tell him, and he would, according to her directions, erve her to the utmot of his power. Both the Strangers gave him a very low Courteie, in token of their thankfulnes; and one of them deiring the patience of his Highnes, and the ret of the Company, eating her elf in the midt of them who had left their dancing to liten to her, he began thus,

div.head: The Story of Faniaca.
div.p: PErhaps this Company, and more particularly that part of it which is of my own Sex, may cenure this freedom in me, and think it too much opennes in a Maid, to dicover things of uch privacy in a publick audience, which the ret of Woman-kind make their Cloet-ecrets; but my Spanih Mitres, upon this very occaion, told me a Story of a Spartan Boy, who having tolen a young Fox, and hidden him under his Gown, rather than be dicovered, kept him there till he tore out his Bowels:

So it is with the Englih Ladies, if once
Love enters into their Breats, though, like that Fox, it prey upon their Hearts, yet out of Modety they keep it ecret; and though the cloer it is hid, it gnaws the fiercer, yet, like the poor proud Boy, they hug it to 'em, and conceal it till it ruins them:
But the Spaniards, and thoe of my Country, who are in a hotter Clime, tye not themelves up to uch cold, uch rigid Rules of Honour:
Your Love, like your Winter Sun, is o clouded, that thoe he hould hine on are never the better for him; ours is o hot and predominant, that there is nothing can cover him:

Now you your elves cannot give a good reaon for this nice piece of Modety, which allows you to take a fancy to a fine Dog, a fine Hore, or any thing ele that is handome, only Man, which is the tateliet, gayet Creature of all, you mut not own a regard for:

Sure this Tyrannical cutom was founded at firt by ome old decrepid Matrons, that were pat the enjoyment of Love themelves; for Nature, that has allowed you the publick freedom of all other pleaures of life, would never conent to digrace this weetet of all:

Whence comes it then, that tho' mot of you are fond of it, yet you manage
it o ecretly, as if it were Treaon to our Sex to own it? While I am in England I hould diemble, like the Englih; but pardon me for once, if I break this general rule, in earching for a Lover, whom I can never find, but by dicovering my elf wherever I come, that ome of thoe who hear me, may chance to bring the ame tory to his Ears, that o he may find me again. My Name is Faniaca, my Father was a Brachman, an Indian Priet in the Province of Antis, which Countrey having never been conquered by the Incas, kept up the ancient Barbarity, not being Civilized by their Laws, as thoe Nations were, who had yielded to their Government:

And whereas they with one conent worhipped the Sun, we of Antis had everal Deities, the two chief of which were the Tyger, and a large Serpent, which we called Amaru: To thee it was our cutom to acrifice Human Blood; they commonly fed on nothing ele but Captives, and if we had no Captives, we were forced to find them the ame ort of Food from among our elves:

But we rarely found any uch want, for there being an irreconcileable Enmity, firt between us and the Incas, and then
with thoe Indians who took part with the Spaniards, we had o frequent Engagements, they to extend their Dominions, and we to defend our own, that carce a day happened, but brought us in ome new Prioners; for the Spaniards had a great Colony at Cozco, and from thence they every now and then ent Parties far into our Countrey to take Booties, and make dicoveries of the Land, in order to a farther Conquet:

Thee Parties were commonly made up of Indians, with Spaniards to head them, becaue they would willingly pare their own Nation, and Conquer ours at the Natives expence. Thee Spaniards till encroached farther on us, till they had driven us over the Madalena, that great River, being very deep, of a trong wift Current, and at that place about a League broad, made it eem as if our differences were now at an end, Nature it elf having divided us:

On each ide of the River there was a coniderable Town, of which, the one was poeed by their Party, the other by ours; and though ometimes our Fihermen would meet by chance and kill, or take one another, yet we never gave one another a troubleome viit on hore, by reaon that
our Canoes were not big enough to tranport Men in o great numbers, as to dare to Land; and it being about 300 Leagues down the Sea, we never had een, or could imagine any which hould hold above ten or twelve men at mot; for our Canoes were made all of a piece, and how to put different Planks together, as Ship-Carpenters do, was an Art wholly unknown to us:

Some of the Spaniards had taught our Enemies this, and they privately built a great many large Flat-bottoms, which the Governour of their Town fill'd with Indians, and ent a few of his own Countrey-men with them; thee Forces he ent over about Mid-night, with orders to Land at our Town, kill all the Men, and ending back the Boats, to keep the Town till he Landed an Army ufficient to fight his way farther into the Country. In this Town my Father lived, and was Priet to the Tiger and an Amanu, which were accounted the larget of any thereabouts, and therefore were worhipped the mot, and had their Adorers to bring them preents from all parts. Thoe Indians who took the Spaniards part, were always very inveterate againt us, becaue the Incas made both
their Government and Religion different from ours; as oon therefore as they entered the Town they kill'd all, without any ditinction either of Sex or Age; I was awakened out of my leep with a dreadful cry, uch as you may imagine that of a taken City to be, where their Enemies are o unmerciful:
