I treight leapt off my Quilt, and ran into my Father's Room, for when by the cry I knew our Enemies to be entered, I expected to loe my Life, and therefore choe to lay it down by him who gave it me:

I found him in a great Conternation, and hanging about his Neck, I expected the coming of our Enemies The firt who entered the Room was a Spaniard; for though I had never een one before, I knew him to be one by his Dres, and a Helmet which he had on as oon as he entered, I left my Father, and fell at his Feet to beg both our Lives; and while I was in that poture, he bade his Souldiers tay back; but one of them cryed out, This is the Cupay, (that is the Devil, or Conjurer) and advancing before the ret, ran at my Father with his Spear; the Commander immediately broke out of my Arms, which were claped about his Knees, and, drawing
a Pitol from under his Girdle, hot the Indian dead; and pulling out the other, he turned about to his Men, and wore that the firt who diobeyed his Orders, as that Dog had done, he'd teach him what was the Dicipline of a Souldier:

While they tood all ilent, amazed at the peedy Jutice he had done on their Country-man, he came to me, who was lying on the Ground bemoaning my Father, whoe Blood tained the Floor, he raied me from the Ground, and clapping a Guard of Souldiers on me, (with orders to keep us two from receiving any violence, upon pain of their Lives) he went away, I uppoe, to help his Part'ners to take the other parts of the Town:

Within an hour after he came back, and pulling a Box out of his Pocket, he took a Plaiter out of it, and put it on my Father's wound, and bad me fear nothing; auring me, that he did not come to detroy us, but to reduce us to a better Government; and as for me, he told me, that if I pleaed, he would make me o happy, that I need not fear any danger, either of Poverty, or Captivity, from the alteration of my condition:

This, and the approach of day-light, did omewhat
comfort me; my Father came to himelf (for los of blood had made him woon) and began in the kindet words he could, to give thanks to the preerver of his Life, who was hugging and comforting me, when of a udden we heard the ame confued noie in the Streets, which we heard in the Night:
I thought our Enemies were finihing their Cruelties upon their Captives, and could not forbear burting into Tears at their Mieries:

The trange Commander endeavoured to comfort me all that he could, aying, That he could not help what the other Captains did to their Prioners, but his own, and particularly my Father and I, hould have no violence offered us:

The noie grew louder and louder, as it drew nearer, when looking out of the Window, we perceived the Antian party driving the Peruvians before them, and before he could reolve what to do, they were killing his own Souldiers at the Door; he with a great deal of Courage leaped forward, and after all his men were kill'd defended the Door alone; and with his Spear laid the boldet of them dead at his Feet:

You will, perhaps, think that I was glad of this change of my Condition, to ee my elf unexpectedly freed, and my Countrymen
revenged of their Enemies; but I'll aure you I was not; the danger which my generous Defender was in, weighed down all the Joy of the other, and though my fear made me for a while tand, as far as I could from the Weapons; yet, at lat my deire to ave him, overcame my Cowardie, and running to the door, I placed my elf betwixt him and the Spears, which were bent againt him; and cryed to my Father to peak to them to let him alone, my Father was o weak with the los of Blood, that he could not come to the Door, but called to them with all the entreating words he could think on; mot of them knew my Father and me, and having a great Veneration for us (as all our Nation has for their Priets) they gave over aaulting him:

Only the foremot of them asked me, why I would defend one who was the Enemy both of our Country and Religion; I told them 'twas to him, that both their Priet and I owed our afety; that he kill'd the Man who hurt my Father, and with a great deal of care dreed his Wound; I deired therefore that, for our akes, they would give me his Life:

Thee words perwaded them to leave him to me; as oon
as they were gone, I went out to ee how things went, and brought him word, that a great Party from the Mountains, was come to our aitance, and that all who et foot on our Land were killed: And, Madam (aid he) hall I be the only man who goes home, and carries the news of o great a defeat? Or hall it be aid, that ever a Spaniard let a Woman beg his Life of an Indian?
Not of one Indian (aid I) for you were over-powered by numbers: No one but you (aid he) hould have given Atolfo his Life; but ince I receive it from you, I'll make that ue of it I hould by erving you, and revenging my elf of my Enemies, for this los and digrace I have uffered. I told him, that ince he confeed his Life was mine, and that I had preerved it, it was not generous to ue that Life againt my Country; however, I left him to his liberty, and promied him, that at Night I would end him over in a Canoe to the other ide:

When Night came, I was as good as my word; and calling two truty Men, I ordered them to row the Stranger over the River, telling them that his preence would be enough to ecure them from the danger of their Enemies:

At our parting he expreed
himelf very thankful to me for my generous uage of him, and told me, that e're long he would make me a return, in the mean he deired me to wear that about my Neck, pulling a Gold Medal, with a Chain of the ame Metal:

I, who had heard of the Spanih Covetounes, gave him a large Golden Wedge, and deiring him never to be my Country's Enemy, or put himelf into the like danger) I took my leave, and left him to his Fortune, the Men came back before morning, and brought me word that they had et him afe on hore, and that all the other ide of the River was covered with Men:

This news, which they told about the Town, alarm'd us, and that Party which came down from the Mountains to our aitance, waited to receive them; ome of our Scouts, who rowed as near the other ide as they durt, brought us word that they had abundance of Canoes fill'd with Men, which made us think they deign'd to Land by force, where the others had by Night; but this was but to amue and draw our Men that way; for they had provided a great number of Planks about 20 mile higher, and having lighted on a place where the River ran between
two Hills, and therefore could not extend it elf a quarter of a Mile, they made a floating Bridge, and on that they paed over ome Men, before ours knew any thing of it; they took uch care to urprize the Natives, that no one came to bring us Intelligence of their being Landed, till ome of the Planks which came floating down the River, made us upect omething; we ent ome Scouts up the River, to dicover what was the matter, and they brought word that the Enmy was on this ide of the River:

Ours marched towards them as fat as they could to fight them, before any more came over, and having joyned Battel, the firt news we heard, was of a great Victory, we had gained over them; and a great many Prioners brought us, as the proof of its being true:

The Indian Prioners were kept up to feed our Gods; but ome few Spaniards that were taken, as being the Nobler Captives, were to be feated on; as it was our Cutom to tye our choice Prioners to a Tree, and a great Fire being made jut by, the Priet was to cut off Slices from the more flehy parts of them, and ditribute them about to the People to broil and eat:

If
the Captive hewed any igns of pain, or groaned at his Sufferings, we counted him of a bae Spirit; and after burning his Body, we cattered his Ahes in the Wind; but if he endured bravely to ee his Fleh eaten, we dryed the Sinews and Bones, and hanging them upon the Mountains, we deify'd them, and went Pilgrimages to them. There were ten Spaniards brought to my Father, and two or 300 Indians, who were all tyed, and ecured by a Guard et over them; the Indians to be a Prey to the Bellies of our Gods, and the Spaniards, to thoe of our Souldiers:
As oon as they were brought in, my Curioity prompted me to ee them, but very little to my atisfaction; for the firt I et my Eyes on was he whom I had et at liberty before:

I was both concerned and amazed to ee him there, and uncertain whether I hould do any thing in his favour or no; therefore I pretended not to know him; till he making as low a bow as his being tyed would permit, asked me, did I not know him whoe Life I had aved? Are you he, aid I, whom I et free but a few days ago? I thought your good uage might have made you our Friend, or at leat your dangerous
ecape might have been a fair warning to you; but ince you are the econd time come amongt our Enemies, and are till plotting my detruction, you hall uffer for your ingratitude, and to hew how little I pity you, I will go to ee you Sacrificed, and eat the firt bit of you my elf. As for the danger of coming again (anwered he) a Spaniard fears none, but I was o far from plotting your detrution, that I hung that Medal about your Neck for my Souldiers to know you by; I had indeed a deign upon your Countrey; but for you, my greatet deire was, by aving you and your Family, to hew how much I aimed to ingratiate my elf into your favour. Thee are all but Wheedles (aid I) to ave your Life; but they hall not erve: No, they hall not (aid he) for ince you can entertain uch mean thoughts as thee of me, I corn to take my Life; all the repentance my attempt has brought upon me is, that it has dipleaed you; I thought to have requited you for giving me liberty, and to have made you amends for the los of your Country, by bringing you to a better, but ince this ill ucces has prevented me,
all that I deire, is to dye in your favour: The way to do that (reply'd I) is to dye undaunted, for then you hall be one of our Gods: I will do o (aid he) be you there, and hew but the leat ign of pity at my death, and I'll go off with uch a Courage, that him whom you lighted whilt he was alive, you hall adore when he is dead. Though in a Man's mouth who was at liberty, this would have looked like a Boat, yet coming from one who did not know but he might uffer next day, it appear'd o brave, that I could not but admire it:
The others held their Tongues, but looked o fierce, as if they kept ilence out of didain:
I went thence with a great opinion of their Courage, and a ecret horrour in my elf at the cruelty of our Nation, which gave brave Men uch barbarous uage:

I called to mind his profeing a deign to ave me, and carry me to a happier place; and his telling me of the thing about my Neck, for a Token to know me by, made me believe it was true; and when I conidered of this, I imagined I ought to ave his Life, but I could not tell how to do it without my Father's conent:

As I came into the Room where he lay ill of his
Wound, there was one brought him word of the death of his only Son; who was found after the Battel among the Slain, with a Bullet lying in him:

I hewed my orrow in all the extravagancies which our Nation commits on the like occaions; but my Father only gave a groan or two, as it were to rouze up his anger, and aid, that he would comfort himelf for his Son, in revenging his Death, ince all his grief could never raie him to Life again:

That all the Spaniards who were in the Battel were killed, except ten who were in his Cutody, and he would acrifice each of them, becaue he would be ure that his Sons Murderer hould not ecape; for ince he was killed with a Bullet, he did not doubt but it was a Spaniard hot him. We lay all that Night awake grieving for my Brother, but the next day, when the firt Fury of our grief was over, and my Father began to talk with me about our Prioners: Suppoe, Father, (aid I) the Spaniard who aved our Lives hould be one of them? If that hould come to pas, (aid my Father) he had better taid where he was, than come over to eek his Death here the econd time: But, Sir, (aid I) gratitude would oblige
us to ave his Life, who aved ours firt: That we have done already (aid my Father) and o we have returned his kindnes; and if after o hard an ecape he hould be come again, he does not deerve his Life, neither would I be guilty of o much injutice to my Son and my Countrey, as to ave that Man's Life, who has been the Death of the one, and has made a econd attempt to be the Detruction of the other. This arguing of my Fathers eemed o reaonable, and his Indignation o jut, that I could not gainay it, and therefore aid no more to him, but went back to my Prioner, and told him, that I did intend to ave him, and his Companions for his ake; but that my Brother's Body being found hot, had o incened my Father, that I could not prevail with him to pare them; and therefore I told them they mut prepare their Courage to dye, as oon as my Father's Wounds would uffer him to ait at the Solemnity.
Well, (ays he) ince I mut dye, and it does not lye in your power to help it, I am orry you told me you attempted it, for that hews o much kindnes, that it makes me deirous to live:
I was willing to dye when you
upbraided me with the begging my life, but now I can no longer be upected to flatter you out of any uch hopes, ince you ay it is not in your power to help me; I own that my Death is no grievance to me, only as it prevents my living for you; and all that I'll now deire of you, is to let me dye the firt, that I may not behold the Cruelties exercied on my Country-men. The Love and Courage which I perceived in thee words, quite altered the thoughts I had, of giving him up to my Father's reentments; and from that time I found omething within me o trong on his ide, that it over-ballanced the Duty I hould have paid to my Father's will, and my Brother's Blood:

I went to my Father, and told him that he who aved his Life was there, and urged to him how ingrateful we hould be, if we did not retore him to his Liberty; but my Father anwered me with the ame Arguments he had done before:

Then I endeavoured to corrupt him that was Captain of the Guard that looked to them, but he was a Blood-thirty violent natured Man, and not only refued me, but complained to my Father, who was o angry, that I hould endeavour to
releae o many of our wort, our mot formidable Enemies, the Spaniards, that he threaten'd, the next time I attempted the like, he would have me condemned to uffer with them, as the Enemy of my Country. I knew his violent temper too well to venture any farther, and gave over all hopes of aving my Prioner:

The next morning four Indians were to be carried to our Gods to feed upon, they drew Lots for their Lives, they were blind-folded when they drew, and I held the Citern, and decided who the Lot fell upon, and it often grieved me to doom the poor trembling Slaves; my Prioner eeing me picking out ome of them for Death, told me, he longed to know when his turn would come; I told him that his mut come as well as the ret; that I had incurred my Father's dipleaure on his account, and left nothing undone which I thought might be for his afety, that I hoped this was all he could expect, and deired him to own before his Death that I was out of his debt; yet I had reolved with my elf to keep him till the lat, in hopes that before that time the Guards might be changed, or ele my Father's anger might be mitigated,
when mot of them had been acrificed to it:

Two or three days had now pat over, in which time my Father had given the Guards particular charge to beware of the Spaniards, for fear I hould free them; the day come that he found himelf well enough to perform the Sacrifice, and our Spaniards were brought out in the midt of their Guards, to draw Lots which of them hould make our Banquet; by ill chance it fell on my Prioner; I changed the Lot, and entenced one of the others in his tead, but not o cleverly but that my Father perceived it:

The poor wretch was cut to pieces lice after lice, and lived long enough to ee his own Fleh broiled, and eaten by the Company; you mut think this was a terrible ight to the ret, who aw by their Companion what they were to uffer. I expected to keep him the ame way I had the firt day, and went on the morrow with the ame deign, little dreaming what would happen; for my Father, who had een me play the Jugler the day before, would hold the Pitcher himelf, and the firt black Lot was again drawn by my Prioner:

Upon that the Fire was made to broil his Fleh, he was tript naked, and tyed
to the Tree; he looked about him, without as much as changing Countenance at his Detiny; but when he turned his Eyes towards me he bluhed, I believe out of hame, to think that I hould ee him in that helples condition:

Such a ight as this, which would have drawn pity even from a merciful Enemy; what effect then do you think it had upon one that loved him? Or rather, what effect had it not? I bluht and grew pale, Anger, Love, and Fear, ucceeded one another; Anger at the Barbarity of my Countrey-men, Love for him, and Fear at his danger:

But jut as my Father's Knife fetched Blood from the brawny part of his Arm (the place which he firt began with) I was not able to bear up any longer, but fell in a woon; which my Father perceiving, left him, and catched me in his Arms; but not having yet recovered trength enough to bear me up, he fell to the Ground with me, and lighting upon his Wound, rubbed the Plaiters off, and made it bleed afreh:

My Father was immediately taken up on ome of their Shoulders, and carried home, and every one aid 'twas an unlucky day, and the Gods were angry, o the Sacrifice
was deferred till the next. When I came to my elf, I was very glad to ee the poor Man delivered from immediate death, though it cot ome of my Father's blood, but it almot ditracted me, to think what a hort reprieve I had for him, only till the next day; his Fate was now at its Criis, and within twenty four hours I mut either ee him free, or mangled to pieces; all my former hopes lay in deferring the time till another Guard came, which perhaps I could have bribed off, or till my Father's mind was altered; but his Anger continued till; and becaue he found the Captain of the Guard as violent againt the Spaniards as himelf, he ordered him to continue in the ame Pot, till all the Spaniards were Sacrificed:
My poor Prioner's Lot was come, and he to dye the next day, and I had not yet thought on any way that could prevent it:
After having wracked my Invention a great while, for a way to free him, at lat I lighted on this:

There were two of my Father's Servants, whom I ent formerly to row my Prioner over the River; I knew they wihed well to him, becaue when he enter'd our Houe as an Enemy, he had aved their Lives; thee
two I acquainted with my deign to releae him:
I gave them a large Pot full of pleaant Liquor, made of our Sacred Plant the Coca, and bade them towards Night to bring that to the Guard-houe, as a preent from my Father:

Our Guard conited of a hundred Men, for the preervation of the Temple, and the Treaures of it, and the Prioners who belonged to it; o that all thee things might well require the care of an hundred Men:
We had near twice the number of Indian Prioners, beides the nine Spaniards, only they were Armed, thee were naked and tied:

Out of the Temple I had got Arms enough for them all, and conveyed them into a Room hard by, to be ready upon occaion; when the two Servants came with the Liquor, all the Souldiers crowded into the Guard-houe, only two who tood to their Arms at the Prion Door; when the Servants aw them all engaged about the drink, they left the Guard, and came to give me notice; upon which I took ome Daggers (which our Souldiers had taken from the Spaniards, and hung up in the Temple as Trophies) thee I hid under my Gown, (for the Women of our Nation had thin ilk Gowns to wear
in the cool of the Night) and o under pretence of eeing the Prioners, I conveyed thee unto them:

When I came in I aw my Prioner aleep, I cut the Cords of his Hands and Legs, and as I cut them he awaked and found himelf looe; thence I went to another, and till as I looened them I put a Dagger in their Hands:

I told them I was come to give them all Liberty, if they would hew themelves Men, and Conquer an Enemy whom they would find urprized, and not ready to oppoe them. And my Atolfo (aid I) I have done all this for your ake, yet I will rather tay behind you, and undergo all the punihments that an angry Father, or incened Town could inflict upon me, than fly with you, unles you are as willing to receive me, as I to go. Several of the Indians wept for Joy, and the Spaniards, for all their Gravity, could carce forbear it:

My Prioner aid, that he was more glad of my Love, than of the aving his Life, and would have told me abundance of the like nature, had he not been interrupted; for one of the Centinels, not liking my long tay, came to ee what was the matter, and no ooner came in but he was tabb'd by one of the Spaniards; my two Servants had
tood all this while at the Door, and when one of the Centinels left them to come to us, they dipatched the other; by this time the Indians had untyed one another, and I carried them to a Chamber hard by, where I had laid the Arms:

Some of the Guard, hearing a noie, chanced to come out, and mitruting omething more than ordinary alarm'd the ret, but they came a little of the latet, for we had as many Armed as they; they began a very bloody Engagement, and a great many were killed on both ides, but our number increaing we over-powered them, and they fled every way for afety. My Prioner had given me in charge to ome of the Indians, who were formerly under his Command, and they kept me in Rear till the Guard fled:

Then Atolfo came to me, and deired me to come down to the River ide, before the Town Guards came upon us, for our noie had alarm'd the Town; and there were at that time five or ix thouand Men which were left with us, for fear thoe on the other ide the River hould make another Invaion; but we were too quick for the uproar, before the Guards came we got to the River,
and there being abundance of Canoes, and the Enemy coming after us, you may gues we did not tand to Complement who hould take Boat firt:
The eight Spaniards, Atolfo, the two Indians and my elf, took the ame Canoe:

We put off altogether as fat as we could, but in a little time we were parted from the ret, the night being o dark that we knew not which way we went, though the Wind blew o hard from the other ide, that we were afraid 'twould force us on our Enemies Coat, to our ruin:

Two of our Spaniards tugg'd againt it as hard as they could, till one of them broke his Oar, and then we gave over triving, and let the Boat go down which way the River would carry it; the next morning we would have made for Shore, but having but one Oar the Wind beat us off, and carried us down all that day and the next night with the Stream. Though the firt day we got away we were very chearful, yet now wanting Proviions, and being driven down we knew not whither, dampt the Joy we hould otherwie have taken in our Love and Liberty:

I began to reflect on my former actions, and to think this a jut punihment for my undutiful leaving
my Father, and my Country; I began to grow faint with hunger, and he was o troubled to ee me in that condition, that in the greatet danger of his Life I never aw him hew o much orrow. The farther we Sailed the River till grew wider and wider; on one ide we could not Land, becaue the Wind would not let us, on the other ide we durt not, becaue 'twas inhabited by thoe Nations who are mortal Enemies to the Spaniards: We were now come down a great way, and the River had turned o, that the Wind, which before was againt us, now was for us; we made towards the Land with the greatet hate that a violent Hunger could make; as we came near the Shore we dicovered a Boat lying under a Rock, we made towards it, and aw only one Man in it, and he was aleep, o that we were upon him before he awaked; he would have reited, but finding it in vain for one Man to fight with eleven, he yielded up himelf and his Boat; in it we found tore of Victuals (the richet prize we could have wihed for at that time) and you may think we fell on to ome purpoe:

We examined the Fellow, and he aid he belonged to a Ship which lay about
ixty Leagues lower; that they ent twenty Men up the River in quet of a Prize which they were to take, by plundering a little Town thereabouts; he told us, that there were about o many more left in the Ship, but that the greatet part of them lay ick of the Wounds they had received in a late Engagement:

We tept into his Boat, and going down the River, in eight days time we came within ight of the Ship; then having got out of the Man what intelligence we thought neceary, we threw him over-board, and made up to the ide of the Pinnace; it being duskih, and they knowing their own Boat again, they mitook us for their own Men; o that half the Spaniards entered, and had killed all that were above Deck, before they mitruted any thing; the ret they took Prioners, and (throwing all the Wounded Men into the Sea) becaue we had not Proviions ufficient to lat us all, they et their Prioners on Shore, and o came down the River merrily in a Ship of our own:

The Spaniards fell to earching, and found ome Bullion in her, beides a vat deal of ready money, which, after a jut diviion between us ten, we computed
would amount to near 30000 Ducats a piece, o that with a general conent we Sail'd treight for Spain, intending to Land at the firt Port of that Kingdom which we came to. Now we were happy enough, we had ecaped our Enemies the Indians, and Famine, which had like to have proved a more fatal Enemy than they; beides the Prize which enriched us beyond our expectation, and came in good time to help my needy Fortune, who in that hurry of leaving home, had not remembered to bring any thing of value with me, beides a few Pearl which I always wore about me. My Servant came and took me in his Arms, congratulating my ecape out of the everal dangers we had been in, and thanking me a thouand times for the kindnes I had hewed in aving his Life; and more for leaving a Father, to run the ame Fortune with him:

In fine, he promied that he would requite all my kindnees, by having me Chritened, and marrying me as oon as we came to Spain: And I was o well pleaed with the alteration of my Condition o much for the better, that I think that Night was one of the pleaantet of my Life. The next Morning we py'd a Sail making up to us, and
as oon as it came within reach, it ent a great Shot to command us to trike Sail; we aw by the bulk that it was a Man of War, too trong for us to reit:

We, much againt our wills, taid for it, and received ome of them on board; in earching our Ship they found divers Colours, as Pyrats uually have; our Veel, it eems, had been one, and for their Faults who had owned her, we were all eiz'd, our Veel made a Prize, and our Men taken Prioners:
The Man of War being a Spaniard, the Captain aid he would reerve Atolfo and his eight Country-men to be tryed on Shore, and condemned to the Gallies:
My two Indians (notwithtanding all my intreaties for their Lives) he hanged on the Ropes before my Face:
But taking compaion on me, he aid he would keep me to wait on his Wife:

I told her he mut buy me a mall Drum, which had never been ued before, and I would then tell her that quetion, and any other. When he heard me affirm it o confidently, he aid he would try me, and bought me a Drum:

I that Night ued ome Charms over it, which my Father and I had practied on uch occaions; and the next morning I told her my Mater would be at home on the morrow: I thought (ays he (laughing) how you could foretell: Why your Mater is gone into the Straights a cruiing, and bade me not expect him thee two Months. I let her enjoy her incredulity, but he had like to have uffered by it; for he, good Woman, conidering that her Captain made long tays and hort returns, had providently looked out for a Gallant, to comfort her in his abence; but I was yet too much a Stranger to be made acquainted with uch privacies. She had an old Spanih Maid, who was the only Servant he
kept, till I came; this Maid was privy to all her Intrigues. They had at that time pitched upon a young Gentleman, who had an Etate near the City, he was very fond of my Mitres, as Men uually are of every new Conquet, and had invited her to pend a few days, in her Husband's abence, at his Countrey Seat:

She conented to go with him, and they had aigned a day to go together, and as it happened, 'twas the very day after that on which my Mater was to come home; but it drawing towards Night, and my Mitres hearing no news of him, nor eeing any likelihood of his coming, he ent her Maid to invite the Gallant to Sup with her; me he ent up to Bed, pretending that he had ome buines for me to rie very early the next morning:
I lay in the Room over her, and though I went to Bed without the upition of any uch treachery againt my Mater, yet chance dicovered it all to me:

I awakened after I thought I had been a pretty while aleep, I fancied I heard a Man's voice in my Mitrees Chamber, and concluded it was my Mater's, becaue I thought my Art would not deceive me; however, my curioity prompted me to a deire of
knowing whether it was he or no:

I got out of Bed oftly, and looking down, I aw her itting at Table, with three dihes of Meat before her; (which in hungry Spain is a noble Treat) by her there was eated a fine young Gentleman, he whom I jut now decribed to you; their dicoure, at that intant, happened to be of me. She told him he had a Slave who pretended to foretell future events; that he had told her that the Captain would be at home that day; the Gentleman laughed, as he aid, to think that a Slave hould be o bold, to impoe uch a Story on her Mitres; he laughed at her too, for giving any belief to me; and I laughed at them both, to think how ecure they fancied they were from my Eyes and my Maters, and yet how much they were mitaken. While I was peeping down, and litening to their dicoure, we heard a loud knocking at the Door; my Mitres cry'd out immediately that it was the Captain's knock, and that he was undone, unles they could hide him omewhere in that Room; for to end him up to mine, was the way to let me know of it, and being a Stranger, perhaps I might betray him to her Husband.
The Gentleman was young and lender; and his Limbs; which eemed compoed rather for Love than War, hew'd that he was a very unequal Match for a great two-handed Sea Captain:

And you have all heard enough of the raging Spanih Jealouie, to think, that if a young handome Man had been found there, and at o upitious a time, 'twould have gone near to have cot all three of them their Lives. The Captain till knocking harder and harder, made them all at their wits end what to do with him; at length they bethought themelves of a great Chet, which my Mater had given his Wife full of Plunder, when he firt came on hore with me; but he had taken all thoe things out, and my Mater had filled it with Sea Bisket, which he had bought for his Men; the Mitres and Maid emptyed thee Biskets out under the Bed, and begg'd the Gentleman to try whether he could get into the Chet; the young Spark was as complying as he could wih him; he made a quick hift to get in, and his Fear was at that time o trong upon him, that it would not only have driven him into that, but into a Moue-hole, if there had been one in the Room:

As oon as he was in, the
Maid let in my Mater, who eemed a little angry that he was kept o long at the door; and eeing the Cloath laid, and the Table covered with Meat, he asked my Mitres how all that came there, and what he deigned with it? I wondered how he would come off; but he very readily anwered, that he provided it for him, and kept him at the Door while he took it from the Fire, that he might be the more urprized, to find o good a Supper ready for him on the Table. He asked how he could provide it for him, ince no Man in Aveiro knew of his coming? My Mitres anwered, that the Indian he had left with her, had told her he would certainly be at home that night. When did he tell you this? (aid he)
Yeterday (anwered my Mitres)
Then, by St. Jago, he is a Witch, (aid my Mater) for yeterday morning, till the Storm came, I did not know (that I hould come) my elf: I hope, Captain, aid my Mitres, you have received no damage by the Storm: None, aid he, but the poiling my tore of Bisket, which got wet, and my poor Men are in want of it; but I will have you, aid he (turning to a Cabbin-Boy that waited on him) go now and call two or three of our Men on
Shore, that we may have hands enough to carry that Chet of Bisket to the Water-ide: Time enough for that to morrow, Love, (aid my Mitres)
No, (ays my Mater) my Men are in preent want of it, and I ought to take care of them, as well as of my elf. The Boy went on his Errand, and my Mitres with a great deal of pain, waited the unlucky coming of the Seamen to carry the Chet away, and her Jewel that was in it. I had till this time been an unconcern'd Spectator, and only pleaed my elf with the fright my Mater's coming had put them in, but now I aw I mut help them out, or they had no way of their own to bring them off; dreing my elf therefore as fat as I could, I went down to them; my Mitres, I believe, wondred to ee me there, when he thought I was aleep, yet he did take no publick notice of it, let my being ent up to Bed, hould give my Mater the greater caue to upect omething. After bidding my Mater wellcome home, I turned to my Mitres: And did I not tell you, Madam, (aid I) that my Mater would be at home to Night? You may ee, (aid he) by my preparations for him, that I believed you: I could not
forbear miling to ee how he would have impoed on me, as he did on my Mater: But, Madam, (anwered I) ince I have given you uch a proof of my skill, which (though it has told you this only for tryals ake yet) hereafter may hew it elf ome way, which may prove more erviceable to you, I would deire one favour of you in its behalf: What's that? (anwered he)
'Tis (aid I) that you would pardon me for an accident which befell me in the performance of it: What's that (ays he) I hope you have not raied any Spirits that have broken our Windows, or done any damage to the Houe: What if they have (aid my Mater) you hall pardon any light michief that they have done:
They have done no michief at all, (aid I) pray do not be affrighted, Madam, and I'll tell you all:
When you were abroad yeterday I et about my Enchantment, to anwer your quetion, but you came home a little too oon, while I was asking ome quetions concerning my own Fortune; hearing you at the Door, and not having time to lay that Spirit which I had raied, I ordered him to throw
the Bisket out of the Chet, and enter into it himelf; you can't but have heard how michievous Spirits are, while they are at liberty, and to preventy any uch michief, I confined him there, till your abence hould give me leiure to lay him:
You went oon after to Bed, and I durt not tell you how near the Spirit was to you, for fear of fright'ning you, nor would at all, had not the preent ue my Mater has of the Chet, forced me to this dicovery: When my Mitres heard this told, he ran to my Mater, and claping him about the middle, pretended to be in the greatet fright imaginable; and deired him to leave me the Houe to my elf, till I had ridded the houe of the Devil. Though the hot Supper, which my Mater believed prepared for him, and my Mitres aying, that 'twas becaue I foretold his coming, had confirmed him in the belief of my Art; and the earnetnes with which I begg'd pardon, made him not quetion what I aid to be true; yet he laughed at the extream fear, which his Wife o excellently counterfeited, and aid, Never fear, Wife, that Mr. Devil, who has been o civil as to lye
there all lat night, will be o rude, as to diturb us now: Sure, Faniaca, he he will not force us to leave our Victuals to cool, to dance attendance on him: If he will give us leave to Sup, we will retire afterwards, and give you leiure to dimis him: Not for the World, (aid my Mitres) I cannot eat one bit, nor enjoy my elf one minute, while the Devil is o near us; dear Love, conider the danger 'tis to be here, and let us go to ome Neighbours, and leave the Witch and the Devil together: Since you are o fearful (aid my Mater) have but patience, till my Men come, and I'll order them to carry the Chet up Stairs, for I am loath to leave this hot Supper; but do not hew your fear to them, for if they know that his Devilhip is in it, 'tis likely they won't venture to meddle with it. My Mitres aid, he thought it long till they came; and I dare wear he did not counterfeit in that, but was at that time as deirous to get rid of her incloed Spark, as ever he was to get into his Company:
The Sea-men kept her not long in pain, for they came while we were talking of them:

My Mater mentioned nothing of the Bisket
to them, but deired, before he at down, that they would remove that Chet up one pair of Stairs for him:

Two of them immediately laid hold on two Rings which were fatened in the ides of it, and heaved it by degrees up tairs, I lighting them the way; the Stairs were o narrow that they could not go both on a breat, but one pulled the Chet up, and the other heav'd it after him, by which means our Gallant was almot tifled in it, for his Head chanced to lie at that end which was lowermot; therefore, when it was near the top, he not being able to endure it any longer, tirred about to lye eaier, and coughed; at which the Men, being tartled, let go, and the weight of the Chet tumbled it down that pair of Stairs, and another pair which joined jut to it; though the Chet was locked, yet the tumbling of it made me expect every moment that it would ly open; and therefore, let it hould dicover the Gentleman, I dropt the Candle:

My Mitres hriek'd at the noie, and clapt too the Room Door where my Mater was; he tood ilent, not knowing what to think of the noie; one of the Seamen tood by me till the Maid brought us
a light, but the other, who bore up the lower end of the Chet, was driven down all the Stairs before it:

I heard the poor Man groan, and was terribly afraid that it was the Gentleman's voice, and that the fall had crippled him; I therefore deired them all to tay in the Room while I went down Stairs, they were willing to obey me, for the horrid noie had put them in uch a Fright, that they tood gazing one at another, wondering what the event would be:

When I came down, I found the Chet open, and the Gentleman gone; then I helped the hurt Man up Stairs; his Head was broken, and ome parts of his Body bruied with the fall, but he was more afraid than hurt. Well, aid my Mitres to me, this comes of your raiing the Devil. The Seaman, who did not know what to make of it before, hearing her ay it was the Devil, concluded it was o indeed; and aid, He was ure 'twas a cloven Foot trod on him, for he felt it, and that he aw the Tail of it, as it went out of the Houe. What, then is he gone (aid my Mitres)
Yes, Madam, he is gone (aid I) and hall trouble you no more: A good riddance (aid he) of your Michievous
Spirits, pray raie no more of them: Then, Madam, (aid I) you mut not give me the occaion. Now my Mitres's real fear was over, her counterfeit one vanihed with it, and bidding us et Chairs, he and my Mater at down; the wounded Man he ent on Ship-board to the Chyrurgeon, and having upped and diverted himelf with the poor imprioned Devil, they went to Bed, where he paed that night with my Mitres, who would rather have had that Devil for her Bedfellow. The next morning my Mitres's Confeour came to her; and my Mater, who was filled with the lat nights adventure, could not contain himelf from communicating it to the Father, aying, That he had given his Wife an Indian, that could raie Spirits, and make them tell her things that were doing at ever o great a ditance; relating, withall, what had happened by that means in his Houe the night before:

The Holy Man, troking up his Beard, with an autere look, told him, that this was no Jet, aid, it was making a compact with the Devil, and that his Chritianity obliged him to confes himelf an Enemy to all uch actions; and
therefore was bound in Concience to dicover this to the Fathers of the Inquiition; and deired my Mater to ecure me:

He aid this when I was by; I was earnet to know what he meant by the Inquiition; but when he told me the danger of coming under the clutches of that bloody Court, and named ome of their Punihments, as the Wheel, Immuring, and other ingenious Cruelties of theirs, I would have given my life for a Maravedy. When my Mater was gone out, I fell down on my knees to my Mitres, and begg'd her to give me my liberty, and put me in ome way to ecape this barbarous tryal, that the Priet would bring me to:

I told her I was loath to mention the kindnes I had done her, in conveying her Spark away, let that hould look like upbraiding her with it; but thus much I mut ay of it, that it was that Story which made the Priet o zealous againt me, and that if ever I came before the Inquiition, Self-preervation would force the truth from me, and that I mut confes the Cheat I put upon my Mater, to avoid the imputation of Witchcraft. See anwered me very civilly, that he had uch a ene of the kindnes I had done her,
that he would requite it with giving me my freedom; and when my Mater came home, he was very urgent till he prevailed with him to do the like; whether he did this out of gratitude to me, or the fear of my threatning a dicovery, I do not know; but my Mater called me to him, and bade me go and hide my elf on board that night, let the Officers hould come to earch for me:

The next day he came on board himelf, and asked me where I would rather Land, I told him in England; for I had conulted my Drum, and was informed, that I hould find my Lover in one of the Northern Ilands, coming from the Siege of a City, and the Rumour of the Hollanders jut then Landing in England, made me think that likely to be the place:

We met at Sea with an Englih Merchant, and giving me a little Money, he put me on board there; I had, beides, ome Money my Mitres gave me at parting, and a Pearl Necklace, with ome Bracelets, which my Mater (finding o great a Prize with us) pared me, when he plundered me at Sea; thee old in England for two hundred Duckets; with ome of this Money I put my elf into an Englih Garb,
keeping my Spanih one by me, and went up to London, and hired my elf to a Peron of Quality; and being an Outlandih Woman, and appearing in a very gentile Dres, I was made her Gentlewoman; I taid with her near a year, in which time I put up a little more Money, and good Cloaths, and learn'd Englih enough, and then I left her, to travel in quet of my Lover:
I went down to Cheter, and hearing that there was a War in Ireland, I embarked for this Kingdom; I have been in Dublin, and am now come hither to follow the Camp, where I am aured I hall find him:
I get as much as maintains me on the Road, by telling Fortunes to the Gentry, who ometimes are very liberal to me:

Amongt the different Fates I read, thoe belonging to Love delight me mot, as being mot agreeable to my own temper; and when ever it lies in my way to forward any of thoe by my Skill, my being in their Circumtances, makes me the readier to help them.

She ended thus, to the admiration of all the Company, whoe Ears were tyed to the Story; The Prince, who was pleas'd with the Wit of the Indian, could not deny her thoe praies that were due to
it; and from her ingenuity in the management of her intrigue, and her contancy in continuing it o long, he concluded that the Spaniard mut needs be happy in her; and told her, that if he was in the Army, whether he were in Commiion, or a private Souldier, he would do what lay in his power to contribute to the finding him out for her, But, he aid, he expected a kindnes of her in retaliation, and that if he earched for her Lover, he would (if need were) do him the ame ervice; that he never gave any credit to Gypies, or any other Vagabonds that pretended to her Talent, but ince he had proved her Skill in o exemplary a manner, he would lay aide his former incredulity, and deire he would atisfy his Curioity in ome things, which it would conduce to his quiet to know. The Indian aid, he would wait on his Highnes, at his Lodgings, the next day, and give him what atisfaction her Art could afford him. But he was not the only Peron that wanted her aitance, neither had the terrours of War o frighten'd Love, as to make him wholly abdicate his power over that Kingdom; but in this Ball he had ome Votaries of both Sexes, and
the ingenious Indian told publickly the place where he Lodged, that thoe whoe Modety retrained them from peaking to her there, might have a more private opportunity. The Prince went home well atisfied with the hopes of knowing his Fortune, and told Celadon that he was o impatient to ee the next day, and the Indian that would atisfie his Doubts, that he found himelf not the leat inclinable to Sleep; therefore, if he would make him a Song, in anwer to that, which he told him he had over-heard his Mitres inging at the Well, he would that Night go Serenade her with it; and though he could neither meet with her at the Ball, nor find her at home, yet this Song would make a dicovery which might alter the reervednes of her Behaviour: Celadon made one; about Midnight they allied out together, and topping under her Window, the Prince, with the bet air which his Guittar and Voice could frame, began this Song, to the ame Tune which he had Sung to hers.

q.l: THe Souldier yields his vanquih'd Heart,
And though he fears no mortal Dart,
The Thunder of your Frowns he flyes,
And dreads the Lightning of your Eyes.

p.U: aid a Voice interrupting him; the Prince looking about, to ee whence the Voice came, aw three naked Swords making towards him: Celadon came up immediately to his aitance; it being o dark, that neither Party could ee to defend themelves, there had been fair work in a mall time, if ome of the Guards, walking the round, had not been pretty near them; when they came up, the three fled, and the Souldiers knowing the Prince, Congratulated his Highnes's ecape, from a Death, which the mot unskillful Enemy might have given him, when there was not light enough to allow him fair play for his Life:

div.p:
They would needs wait on him home, and he conidering that the noie might have allarm'd ome of the Neighbours, thought it bet to retire, for fear of raiing a dicoure, which might prove prejudicial to his Mitres, and offend
her. The next Afternoon the two Strangers came to wait on the Prince, and finding him alone, one of them told him, he was come to make good her promie, that he brought her Companion with her, who undertood nothing but Spanih; however, if his Highnes had any ecret extraordinary to communicate to her, he would go with him to another end of the Room; the Prince opening a Cloet Door, retired in thither with her, and opened his mind in thee words:
Since I want uch advice, as cannot rightly be given, without ome fore-knowledge of what will be the iue of it, and ince my buines is nothing but an Amour, who o fit to conult about it as you, who are a Fortune-teller, and a Lover too? You may undertand then, that my buines is nothing but Love; it is one o violent, and yet o unreaonable, that I am unable to curb it, nor have I any hopes of ucces, if I let it go on; and 'tis jut with me now, as with a Souldier, whom his too boyling Valour has engaged o far in the Battel, that his Enemies have urrounded him; there's no retreating for him, becaue the Foe is behind, nor any likelihood of breaking
through, becaue there are too many before him:
So am I urrounded with difficulties, puhed forward by Love, and oppoed by Depair; carried on by her Charms, and driven back by her Didain; now I would know what my ucces may be, if I go on, and accordingly I will either nourih this Paion, or tear it from my Breat?
I cannot ee, (aid the Indian) what hould dicourage your Highnes from proceeding, ince there are thoe perfections in your Highnes, which give you deert enough to pretend to the bet of Women:
I fancy your Highnes has fallen in Love with ome one below you, and that your Love and Ambition are at variance, whether that hall draw Love up, or Love draw that down:
I know thee two generally tend two contrary ways, that one, like Earth, decending, the other, like Fire, till apiring upwards.
You gues as right, (aid the Prince) as if you had een my Heart; and if you can tell me how I hall ucceed in my Love, I'll make that, or my Ambition, conform it elf to the other:
I doat on one who is beneath me; when I made my firt Addrees, he eemed Pliant enough, as
if he had no averion to my Love; nay, I over-heard her once confeing to a Confident, that he had a kindnes for me; and when I thought her my own, I found my elf mot deceived; for ome Capricio or other made her, that he would never ince admit me into her Company; I went everal times to enquire for her at home, but the Servant till hifted me off, either denying her, or pretending he was ick; I contrived lat Night's Ball, in hopes to entice her thither, but it failed; I Serenaded her lat Night with a Song, in anwer to one I heard her Sing, that time he confeed a Love for me, but before it was ended, I was interrupted by ome Night Adventurer, who attempted to kill me, which makes me upect 'tis ome Rival; inform me by your Art, whether this is a Favourite that upplants me in her Heart, or whether it be Virgin Nicenes, Hypocritical Modety, or what ele it is that has put this udden top to my Succes?
This is a puzzling quetion (aid the Indian ) but give me one Night's time to conult my Drum about it, and I will bring you an anwer. The Prince eemed well contented, and the two Strangers,
taking their leaves of him, left him to expect the inight the next day would give him of his Fortune. On the morrow they came again, and the Prince took the Indian into the Cloet (as he had done the day before) and deired her to be as plain as he could, in foretelling him all that was to befall him in his Love:

Firt, (aid he) your Highnes mut acquaint me whether you deign Marriage, or no. Marriage! (aid the Prince) why did not I confes to you, that he was a private Gentlewoman, one beneath me? I wonder you hould ask uch a quetion:

Pray, Sir, be not angry, (reply'd the Indian) for how can I tell your Highnes what ucces you are like to have in any deign, until I know the deign it elf? If (anwer'd he) I can enjoy her on any terms, but thoe of Marriage, I hall think my elf very happy; if not, my Love has o wholly blinded me, as to make me forget my Interet, and my Honour. Your Highnes (aid he) is certainly very prudent, in having o great a command over your Love; and pray make ue of it, when I hall tell you the tate of your Affairs:

The Lady you Love, has a Gentleman who loves her as violently as you, only
a more honourable way:

Your Highnes's Fortune has altogether the acendant over his, if you are inclined to lay hold of that advantage, if not, my Art tells me, that, within a Week, he will be too far off for you to enjoy, or ever to ee her again. And is this all the hopes you can give me? (aid the Prince) Yes, (aid he) only thus much I may add, that your Fortune promies you a great deal of happines, if ever you have her; but if you Love, I need not tell you this, for Love injoy'd is always happy; ince, if there be uch a thing as happines, it is to be in that condition which is mot delightful to us; being in poeion of what we Love, is being in the condition which is mot delightful to us, and thence may well pretend to be the highet of Enjoyments. I ee you are o Indulgent (aid the Prince) as to humour me in my Love, but that is detructive to me, and therefore we'll talk of it no more; there's omething (aid he) by way of gratification, for the trouble I have put you to:

The Indian told him, he would not receive any uch reward, for the unwelcome news he had brought him; that all the requital he deired, was his Highnes's favour
to the Spaniard, if ever he found him:
Only deired his Highnes to take her advice, never to put himelf to the trouble of another attempt on his Mitres, unles 'twas with a deign of Marriage, for her Art declared it would prove unuccesful:

That if his Highnes ever wanted her help in this, or any other buines, he might find her in this Town, where he reolved to tay, till the Army was marched through it to Limerick, becaue that was the likeliet way to find out her Lover. With thee words he took her leave, and taking her Companion with her, left the Prince in the greatet ditraction of thought imaginable:

The aurance which the Indian had given him, that he mut expect no ucces, unles in a Vertuous Love, made him reolve to hake off the mean Paion; but all his endeavours were vain; the more he tryed it, the more enible he grew, how unable he was to perform it:

He advied with Celadon, and they agreed to carry on the Intrigue, in pight of what the Indian foretold; and this agreed bet with the Prince's humour, who, though he could not entertain the thoughts of Marrying her, could les endure the thoughts of loing her. They
contrived to have it thought about Town, that Celadon had fallen into the Prince's dipleaure; the Prince hewed the firt igns of it in Houe, and they of the Houe oon reported it abroad; Celadon, with a eeming dicontent, left the Prince, and went to Lodge with one of the Officers, at Marinda's Mother's:

There was a young Gentlewoman, a Couin of Marinda's, and her chief Confident, the ame whom the Prince had heard talking with her at the Well, the only comfort of her Parents, who were worth above ten thouand Ducats, of which, their Deaths would leave her the entire Poeour; he was withal very Witty, and good Humoured; but Nature and Fortune, who not often agree to be over-kind to the ame peron, had here followed their uual Cutom, making her want in Beauty, what he had in Riches:

And as her Wit was keen, and harp, upon all that came into her Company, o Nature had given you an exact Copy of her inide, by her out-ide; for her Face had as much of Satyr in it, as her Tongue; the Chin of it was harp and long, the Noe tucked up, as if it fled from her Mouth, which was o wide, as if Nature
had deigned it for ome Cormorant Body:

Her Face was all over tudded with Freckles, which, like the Stars in the milky way, lay o thick, that you would have thought it one continued yellownes; only her Cheeks, which had a red Colour, but uch a tawny one, as that of blated Goosberries. This Gentlewoman was then in Town with Marinda's Mother, who was her Aunt, and he was an excellent help to her Couin, both diverting her from Melancholly with her Company, and helping her with her Advice:

When Celadon came to Lodge there, he became acquainted with her; and having remembered, that he once had ome dicoure with her, while the Prince was entertaining her Couin, he call'd to mind, how Witty and Pleaant he that time found her Converation:

Their being in the ame Houe, made them often in one anothers Company, and in a little time they grew to a great Familiarity. Celadon, hearing what a coniderable Fortune he had, made his Addrees to her in earnet, but found her till grow trange, when he poke to her of that, and therefore thought that omething extraordinary was the caue of it:
in the mean time the Prince grew reconciled to Celadon, and as their falling out, was only a pretence for Celadon's leaving him to Lodge there, o the Prince now made ue of that priviledge to his own advantage; for now Marinda could no longer avoid him; and though he did as often as he could, yet he came o often thither, that ometimes he lighted on her before he was aware: Celadon's Chamber was on the ame floor with hers, and nothing but a mall Gallery divided them; her Chamber was jut at the Stair-head, and the Prince would ometimes, as he came up Stairs, find her Door open, and then force himelf into her Company:
He this way had frequent acces to her, yet could never gain from her the leat word in his Favour:

In this poture his Amour was, when an Expres came to him, that the King had et out of Dublin, on his March to Limerick; the Prince gave the Officers notice to have all the Souldiers in Arms the next day to receive him:
He went treight to ee Marinda, becaue he did not know but the King might take him along with him, as he came through the Town, and o not give him time to take his leave of her:

He came into her Mother's,
and being ued to go often thither to Celadon, went up Stairs, without peaking to any body; not eeing her below, he went into her Room, but not finding here there, and eeing her Cloet-door open, and a Pen and Ink on the Table, he pulled the Door cloe, and at down to write a Billet Deux, which he intended to leave for her:

In the mean while Marinda came into the Room, and this Couin with her, and itting down, they carried on a dicoure, the firt words of which the Prince did not hear, but the following were to this purpoe:

I tell you, Marinda, (aid the Stranger) 'tis in a happy hour for you, that the King is coming down, for he will take thee Souldiers with him, and this Prince, who is o ungentile to endeavour the ruin of a Gentlewoman:

I hould carce blame him (aid Marinda) for why hould a Man be blamed for proecuting the way to his own happines? Nor am I o conceited, as to aim at Marriage; for what private Gentlewoman could nourih uch vain hopes as thoe, of being raied to a Princes? 'Tis more than a bare Prodigy, for Earthquakes, Inundations, and thoe wonders of Nature do ometimes happen; but that a
Prince hould marry a private Maid, is uch a wonder, as I never found mentioned in all the Chronicles I have read. What? Couin, (ays he) and do you plead for him! will you ever conent to his Love on dihonourable terms? No, (aid Marinda) as I do his Caue Jutice, o I will my own; had not this news of the King's coming prevented me, I would have gone with you to your Father's, to avoid him; now I will deferr it till I hear the Siege of Limerick is over, then I will retire to your Houe, or ome other Relations, where he hall never trouble me again, or I him. Ay, do, Marinda, (aid her Couin) fly the Tempter:

But what hall I do with my Lovers? They are both going to the Camp, and will expect that I give them ome atisfactory anwer; and I do not know which way to incline; the one is a Captain of Hore, he is approved of by my Father, but diliked by my Mother and me, becaue he is a Papit, and I have another caue of averion for him, that is, that he is a Foreigner; I don't fear that all his Country Jealouie can make him upitious of uch a Face as mine; but thoe on the continent make uch aucy domineering Husbands,
that no free-born Irih-woman will endure their lavery:

There is Celadon a good Humoured, Handome, Witty Fellow, and one that I like very well; he makes his Courthip o zealouly, and wears o eriouly that he Loves me, that I do almot believe him; yet the Fellow is o poor, that I fancy neither Father nor Mother will ever conent to my having him; prithee tell me what reolution to take; or whether of the two to favour, my inclination, or my Obedience. There is (aid Marinda) come to this Town an Indian, who tells Fortunes very true:

Shall we (aid he) put on our Masks, and go to her? No, (aid Marinda) he will come to me for ending for; I was the firt that received her in this Town, and wellcom'd her as a Stranger, and therefore he is very intimate with me:

Then pray (aid the Stranger) let us end for her immediately: 'Tis not a fit time (aid Marinda) but in the Afternoon I will end her a Meage by my Maid, and he hall bring her with her; but we are ummoned, here's a Servant come to call us to Dinner. They went down together, and the Prince tole oftly to Celadon's Room, and finding him within,
bade him come along with him to his Lodgings; and he bearing the Prince company out, no body upected, but he had all the while been in Celadon's Chamber. As the Prince walked towards his Lodging, he told Celadon of his lying hid in the Cloet, and all that he over-heard them aying. And now Celadon, (aid he) what think you of my Condition? What hould I think, (anwered Celadon) but that you are happy? for you love and are beloved:

But what good will that Love do me (reply'd he) ince 'twill never avail me any farther than the bare acknowledgment? Nay, that he Loves me is rather my unhappines, for did he not, perhaps he would continue here, and I might have thoe maller atisfactions, the ight of her, and her Converation:

And I would rather have her Company, though he tortur'd me with didain, than loe her by this effect of her Love. Your Highnes (aid Celadon) has better Politicks in War than in Love; if in the Battel your Enemy hould fly, would you grieve that he did not tand longer, does not his flight do better? If he had trength enough to reit he'd tand; but he, like him, in her flight confees
her weaknes, and in retiring before you does eem to ay, Come follow me, and Conquer. Your Highnes aw her Couin, my Mitres, though her Face is very ordinary, yet her Shape is handome; he has a very taking Wit, and I hear he has a Bag of Money would blind one ooner, than the mot dazling Beauty:

And (as I am a Souldier) though I have a great devoir for all the Beauties of the fairer Sex, yet, to my thinking, rich Jewels out-hine the brightet Eyes, and the yellow of the Leuidores is a more glorious colour, than the fairet White and Red, that ever made Lover doat, or Poet Rhime:

I am glad they will end to the Indian, for I'll tell them their Fortunes, and order them too, but o much to our advantage, that you hall have your Mitres, and I mine; the way I will go about it hall be this:

Your Highnes may deire your Landladies pretty Niece to take her Maid with her, and go to the Indian to know her Fortune, let her order the Maid in the mean time to tay at the Door, and when the Servant comes from Marinda, let her pretend to be the Indian's Servant, and to carry the meage up Stairs; let her bring the Servant down word, that her Mitres,
the Indian, is buie with Company, but will wait upon her Lady in the Evening; then let the young Gentlewoman gratify the Indian well for telling her Fortune, and tell her that he has a mind to have a Frollick that Night, and deire the Indian to lend her one of her Spanih Suits to Maquerade in:

When he has brought this Suit home, I will put it on, and go to Marinda's at the appointed time; I will peronate the Indian, my feigned Voice is hrill enough to pas for a Womans, you know I have got a Foreign tone, as well as he, my height and hape are much the ame, and for my Face 'tis no matter, he always wears a Veil, o will I, and as to her gift of Fortune-telling, let me alone to tickle their Fancies. The Prince was mightily pleas'd with the Stratagem, and aid, Go on and proper, thou cunning Proteus, and may Celadon the Prophetes have better luck than Celadon the Francican. The Prince ent up for the young Gentlewoman, and telling her that there was an Indian come to Town, who hewed none but Gentry their Fortunes, he deired her to go this Afternoon to ask hers; and told her, that he mut borrow a Spanih Suit of the Indian, as for
her elf:

He gave her a Pure of Gold to pay the expence, and leave as a pawn for the Cloaths, in cae the Indian, not knowing her, hould be unwilling to venture them without Security. The young Gentlewoman took her Maid with her, and did her buines as uccesfully as they could wih:

She had her Fortune told, and the Prince, to whom formerly he made the whole Relation of her Amour, was deirous to know what the event of it would be. She told him, that the Indian, miling, delivered it in thee words; Be Contant, and be Happy. Thank your kind Fortune, Madam, (aid the Prince) how many a Lover would be over-joy'd at uch a Prediction! He pake this with a particular earnetnes:

The Fair Virgin gave the Prince thanks, for ending her to know it, and took her leave of him, not without oberving omething extraordinary in his Countenance, by which he gues'd that the impartial God of Love, has no more repect for Perons of Quality, than for their Inferiours. Celadon fell to hifting himelf, and having put on the Indian's Habit, looked o like her, that the Prince promied himelf both Diverion and Succes from this adventure.
Celadon taid till it grew duskih, becaue the Night would help the diguie; about an hour after he came back again, and gave the Prince this account of his Succes. I have been at Marinda's, he took me into the Cloet (where you was) very cautiouly, let any one hould hear but her Couin and me, not dreaming who he confeed her elf to:

She told me that he did Love you, and yet mut diemble it; that he heard your Highnes had been in the Houe, and he thought 'twas to ee her; that he expected you would come to take your leave of her, and did not know how he ought to receive you:

She aid that I told her at firt, that he hould have you, but now deired me to confes freely, whether I poke truth then, or did it to flatter her humour; for if it were o, he would not indulge her elf the ight of you any more, but wean her elf from you for altogether. I found by this, that the Indian had oothed her up with the hopes of your Marrying her; I humoured her too, and bade her hope the bet:

For had I done contrary, that would have contradicted what the Indian told her, and given her ome grounds to upect me for a Cheat; beides, depair
