might have made her refrain your Company for ever:

She ighed, and aid, he would ask my Advice, whenever he had occaion for it. Then her pert Couin took me up, telling me much the ame tory that you over-heard her in, and deired to know which of thee Lovers he hould have:
Your Highnes may imagine I gave the Verdict on my own ide:

And after threatning her with all the ill fortune, that can be in the other Servant, I promied her as much happines in my elf; and was o large in my own praies, that it made me bluh, under my Veil, while I uttered them. She proffered me a reward for what Advice I gave her, yet would not tell me whether he would take it or no. But when I had parted with them, and thought the Joke was over, the pleaantet part of it was to come; for at the Door I met a pretty young Lady, who was come to pay a viit to Marinda: I was at the Ball (ays he) when you profeed the faculty you have, in fore-telling Events, and now I have met you in a private Houe, I mut needs make tryal of it; aying this, he took me aide, and having conjured me Secreie, he told me, that he lived in Dublin,
and was ardently ollicited by one Kâ€”k, a great Officer in the Army; that he made her vat promies of kindnes and everlating Affection; and he deired to know whether he would prove Contant, if he truted him:

After having looked fixedly on her Face, and the palms of her Hands, and ued thoe impertinent Formalities, that your pretended Fortune-tellers do, I bade her never doubt it, my Life for it he would prove true. She could not conceal the Joy he conceived, at my favourable anwer; and for my good news, and to bribe me to Secrecy, he clapp'd a Jacobus into my Hand. I hope your Highnes will not blame me, for cozening the poor Maid, for I thought it might prove my own cae another time, to deire one to have the ame good Opinion of me, and therefore I thought I ought to do, as I would be done by. In the Street I was topped again, by a pruce Servant Maid, who making a low Curteie or two, deired me to look in her Hand, and give her a proof of my Skill; he brought me into a Kitchen, to a light, and hewed me her Hand, but begg'd me to be ecret, becaue it concerned her Reputation:

I told her, he
might peak freely to one who knew not her Name, nor was ever likely to ee her again. I am Courted (aid he) by an Old Man, who is very Rich; I love a Young one, who as very poor:
The Young one I dare not marry, for fear of Beggery; the Old one I mut not, becaue I cannot endure him:

In this uncertainty I would live as I am, were it not that the young Man took his advantage on me in the Critical minute; and now I mut make choice of one, or the other, for fear of being with Child, and for ever digraced; tell me, in this cae, which will thrive bet with me. I remember'd I was Celadon till, for all my Habit, and therefore conidering the neceities of thoe Youths, whoe niggardly Fortune would not let them Marry, and the Dotage of feeble old Age, that will needs be Lovers, when their eaon's pat, I advied her to Marry the Old Man, and keep the Young one; that way (aid I) you will enjoy the Love of the one, and the Riches of the other. Her Mater coming in at that time, and asking what I was, the Maid told him, I was a Fortune-teller:
Go thy ways, Girl, (aid he) and leave me to peak a word to her:

When he
was gone, he pulled out a Silver Groat, telling me, I hould have that to reolve him a quetion. Sir, (aid I) though I ometimes tell the Poor their Fortunes for nothing, yet I never do it to the Rich under half a piece. I am not one of your ignorant rambling Gypies; I'll tell you your Fortune, as it hall fall out to a Hair:
Well, here's half a Piece for you, (aid he) if you tell it o exactly, for 'tis a thing of moment:

I am about to marry a handome Girl; the only cruple I have againt it, is, that thee young Jigglets are o wild, that I fear 'twill be hard to keep her contant; tell me therefore, whether he will be true to me, or no? What Age are you of, (aid I)? But threecore and eight, (aid he): I looked in his Hand, and took his Gold, and told him, that the Virgin would prove as honet to him after Marriage, as he was to her Vertue, before he Weds her. This was a true anwer, for I fancied it was his own Maid that he meant, and how honet he was, I knew by her own Confeion. I went away laughing at the folly of Covetous old Age, that would throw more Money away, towards the atisfying an impotent deire, than he would willingly
have given a Phyician, for the aving his Life. The Prince laugh'd at the pleaant ue which Celadon had made of his diguie; and they two debated for a while which was the greater weaknes, that of the Old Man, to trut his Honour to a Young Woman's Vertue; or that of the Maiden, to trut hers to the Contancy of an Officer. The Prince placed his own Folly in the firt rank; and aid, it was greater than the other two, to trut all the repoe and quiet of his Life, to the rigour of a didainful Woman; to cringe to one that was beneath him, and ubmit himelf to one, who could not pretend to a higher Match, than one of his Dependants:

But when Love tock her part, it made him recant all thee Reflections, clad the meannes of his paion in a lovelier dres, and made it eem, either no fault at all, or one of the leat, the mot pardonable of his Life. He commended Celadon's dicretion, in indulging her the hopes of Marrying him, for fear her Vertue hould otherwie have made her hun him. The next morning word was brought to the Prince, that the King was near the Town:

He drew up all his Men, in order to receive his Majety;
and after having kied his Hand, and dicoured with him, concerning the preparations requiite to the Siege, the Prince came home to put all things in readines for his next days March:

But that which he accounted the chief, was to take his leave of Marinda. He found her alone in her Room; and though he eemed uneaie, yet he contrained her to tay, and hear a long tory of his Paion; which he et forth in the mot prevailing words, accompanied with the mot winning Carriage, that Art and Nature, joyned together, could invent. At lat he gain'd o much upon her, as that he conented to receive a Letter from him, while he was in the Camp. He came back to Celadon with a mixture of Gladnes and Sorrow; Gladnes at the favour he had granted him, the priviledge of Writing to her; and Sorrow to think that he mut purchae that atisfaction at o dear a rate, as the los of her Company, as long as the Siege hould continue. I will not et down how many of thee Fits of Joy and Grief he had, whilt he was in the Camp; neither will I Romance o much, as to white down all the thoughts he had of her, and all the many wie Dialogues
he had with himelf about her; thoe the Reader can better imagine, than the Author tell; at leat, if he has any of the ame Paion the Prince was poeed with:

That will make him ympathize exactly with his Highnes's thoughts, as two Clocks, well made, keep time with one another. Thus much I know, that they were o importunate with him, that they could neither be lull'd aleep, by the tillnes of the Night, nor diverted by the terrors of the Day:

They kept him company continually, followed him even into the Enemies Trenches, and when Shot of all orts flew thicket about his Ears, they were neither till'd by the noie of the greater, nor frighten'd away by the mall. Among all thee thoughts, he did not forget thoe of writing to her; nor had he been three Weeks away, when calling to him one of his trutiet Servants, he ordered him to take Hore for Clonmell, and, with all the privacy imaginable, deliver her this Letter.

body.p: IF I could think that Abence would have the ame effect on you, it has on me, I hould be but too happy:

Might I hope that it has leened your Didain, as much as it has encreaed my Love, I hould be over paid for all the retles hours, and melancholly thoughts it has cot me. But this is too good Fortune for me to flatter my elf with; nor is it likely, that he who huns her preent Lover, hould cherih his memory when abent. We have block'd your Enemies up, won a Fort from them, and daily gain more ground:

And O that I were as certain of Conquering you; as of taking the Town! But you, my lovely tubborn Enemy, hold out againt all
my endeavours:

All the Aaults I make erve but to hew your Obtinacy, and my Weaknes, and help to confirm the improbability of my gaining you. Yet Depair it elf hall not make me give over; but like a reolute General, who will rather dye in the Trenches, than rie from before the Town which he has once laid Siege to; o after all your Repules, my wort of Fortune hall but make me dye at her Feet, whoe Heart I could never gain entrance to. But do not rahly reolve on my Ruin, but conider, my Lovely Princes, whether it is not juter for your Pity to indulge that Paion, which your Didain cannot detroy:
And o intead of proving the death of your Lover, give him his Life, in letting him live to be

div.p: The Prince awaited the return of his Meenger with a great deal of Impatiency:

The next Evening, as he came from an Aault, his Man came to him; and having told his Highnes that he had performed his Meage to Marinda, he gave the Prince a Letter from her, which he opened, after kiing the Seal, and, with a great deal of Pleaure, read thee words.

body.p: WHen I received the Honour of a Letter from your Highnes, I was in a great trait, whether to return an Anwer to it or no:
If I did, I thought it would look like Preumption; if not, like Incivility:

In this hard choice I thought it bet to err on the kinder ide, and rather incurr the cenure of Rudenes, than that of Ingratitude. How little I am guilty of the latter, your Highnes, too well knows, by being witnes to a dicoure, which I never deign'd for your Ears; but ince it
came to them, I cannot recant it. And though your Highnes talks of depairing to take the Town, I can't think you hould, when you know how much you have gain'd of it already:

But your Highnes deals harder with this, than you do with Limerick; you'll offer no Conditions, becaue you expect it will urrender upon Dicretion; you hope that in vain: for though a Traitor within takes your part, and all the cunning you have aaults it from without, yet thee ways will not render your Highnes Mater of this Fort, which will never yield, but upon Honourable Terms.

closer.signed: Your Highnes's Mot humble Servant, Marinda.

div.p: The meaning of this Letter was too plain, to have any fale Contructions made upon it; and the Prince, who aw that he mut retire, or engage too far, had now a greater conflict with his thoughts, than he had before with the Coynes of his Mitres, he was o equally divided betwixt Love and Interet, that they governed his Breat by turns, ometimes one having the better, and ometimes the other. He thought, however, that o kind a Letter as this eemed to require an anwer; and therefore, upon the Army's taking the Irih-Town, uppoing that a little more time would render the King Mater of Limerick, he wrote her this anwer, to prepare him a kind Reception, when the Camp hould break up.

body.p:
AS our taking the Irih-Town has prepared our way towards the taking of Limerick, o I hope the Surrendry of Limerick will prepare
mine, towards the taking that which I value above all the Cities of the nivere, my Lovely Marinda; and my hopes will be mightily cros'd, if one Month does not put me in poeion both of that, and her:

She hall then ee how much better conditions we'll give her, than we do to our Enemies; when we hall make them accept of what Terms the Conquerour pleaes to impoe; but my Beautious Fortres, even when he has Surrender'd, hall chue her own Conditions, and impoe what Laws he pleaes on her Conquerour:
Since, as he receives that Title only from her Favours, o will he any time exchange it, for that of the

div.p: In this Letter, the Prince pake what he truly thought, that Limerick would oon be taken; for the King had ent for ome heavy Cannon to the Camp, to throw down the walls, and a breach once made, there were thouands of Englih bold enough to have dared all the Enemies Shot, and force their way into the Town, in pite of all the reitance:

But Fortune had otherwie ordered it, for Sarsfeild with an unuual Bravery, marched with a mall Body of Hore, farther into that part of the Country which was Subjected to the Englih Power, than they upected he durt; urprized the Convoy, and cutting them to pieces, burnt them, their Carriages and Proviions, (which they brought for the Army) to ahes; ome of the Carriages he nailed up, and burt the ret; and the Army wanting them to batter the walls, and the haty approach of the Winter, not giving them time to end for others, they raied the Siege; his Majety went for England; his Forces retired to their winter Quarters, and our Prince to his Mitres. I trut, the Reader will not think it prejudicial to our Prince's Honour, to come back without taking the Town, this
was not his fault, but his Fortunes; the days of Errantry are pat, nor have our Warriours now, uch Swords as thoe Knights of old, that could hew a way through the thicket walls, and do wonders greater than our Age will believe:

Our Prince did not pretend to impoible Exploits, but as far as pure Natural Force, and Courage could go; he might have been ranked in the firt File of the Army; he was not ahamed, that he could not do impoibilities, but came back to Clonmell with as brisk a Look, and as glad a Heart, as if he had Routed Sarsfeild, and laid Limerick in Ahes. The place where he Lodg'd before, was made ready for him, but he had other deigns, and therefore Complemented ome of the other Officers with thoe Quarters, and choe Marinda's Mothers for his. But when he firt accoted his long abent Mitres, 'twas in Terms o paionate, that the inability of the Author makes, him forbear to expres them; nor could he match them, though he borrowed Apollo's Brain to invent, and a Quill plucked from one of Cupid's Wings to write them down; neither would he think it afe to expres them to the Life if he could, let a
Paion o well repreented might prove infectious to thoe that Read it; and uch Charming Words like thoe in Magical Books, might raie a Spirit in ome Fair Reader's Mind, ome rampant Spirit, that would make the Raier his prey, before he would be able to lay him again:
Thus much the Author will aure you, that they had as powerful an effect, as he could deire over his Mitres; or as the mot Amorous of my Readers could wih to have over his own:

She laid aide that reervednes which he oberved to other Men, and confeed her Love, as freely as he gave it him; that Night, he told Celadon of the welcome he received; and Celadon asked him, whether he intended to Marry her? This Quetion put the Prince to a tand, and he asked Celadon whether there was any poibility of Enjoying her without it: Celadon told his Highnes, he would try, and acquainted him with the vvay, and the Prince approving of it, the next afternoon he put it in Execution:

He went to wait on Marinda's Couin, whom he Courted, and they two being pretty Familiar, the young Gentlewoman began to talk about the Love the Prince bare
her Couin; he did it to ound him, and to find whether the Prince's Affection was real. Celadon, who watched for uch an opportunity, aid, yes truly, the Prince had an unfeigned Affection for her fair Couin, o violent a one, that notwithtanding the difference of Quality, the Prince would Marry her if he were ingle. What, is he Married then aid the young Lady, extreamly urpriz'd? Why, did not you know it, Madam, aid he? ince through inadvertency I have blabb'd it out, for Heaven's ake do not let it be known that it came from me, for then I hall be for ever out of the Prince's favour. She promied he would not, and o left him, to carry the News of it with all peed to her Couin. The Prince having left a great part of his Men in Clonmell, was gone out of Town that Morning at the Head of the ret, accompanying the gros of the Army which was Marching towards Dublin; and on the morrow about mid-day, he took leave of the Officers, to return to Clonmell; he brought but one Man back to wait on him, who had a Horeman's uual Arms, Sword and Pitols, and the Prince had a flight Morin on, and a Buff-coat, both
which he wore, rather for the olemnity ake, (becaue he went with the Army) than for any ue he upected he hould have of them:

Riding along, they came to diverity of Roads; where he and his Man being both Strangers to the Country, lot their way, nor could they meet with any one to direct them into it, only the Voice of ome body in a wood jut before them; when they drew nearer, they heard the hrieks as of one in ditres, and the Prince Riding up, overtook his Man, and put on as hard as he could to ee what it meaned; coming nigh, he aw by a Hedge ide two Men, who had defended a gap againt twelve, one of them was fallen, and block'd up that place in his Death, which he maintained whilt alive; but was not unrevenged, for two were killed on the other ide, and the other Peron tood armed with Anger and Depair, and with more Courage than Hopes, maintained the Combat againt o unequal a number; the ingle Peron eemed by his Garb to be a Gentleman, he had only a half-pike, which he managed o actively, that with it, he kept off a row of pitch-forks and Swords, which aaulted him; behind him, tood
Lady and her Maid, crying out at every thrut they made at him, and calling upon Heaven and Earth for aitance, againt thoe barbarous Enemies:

The Prince rode up, and commanded them to deit, and let him know what was the caue of their Quarrel; one of them gave him a hort Anwer in Irih, and at the ame time made a thrut at him with his Pitch-fork, which by the Prince's udden purring his Hore mied him, and ran the Beat into the belly, the Prince drawing out a Pitol, returned the Irihman's Complement with a hot, and laid him dead at his Hore's feet; he had done the ame ervice with his other Pitol, but that the Beat enraged with the double wound which Teague's weapon had given him, kick'd and flung o, that the Prince was forced to alight; the Man which waited on his Highnes, did more Execution with his Pitols, and having with them, killed one, and wounded another, he alighted and drew his Sword to Fight by his Mater, who by this time had dipatch'd two more, not without receiving a great wound, which one of them with a half-pike had given him in the ide; the Prince enrag'd at that, fell
fiercer on the ret, and the Stranger who hitherto had been only on the defencive part, having but one to deal with, gave him his mittimus to the other World, and came up to fall on thoe who had more than their hands-full of the Prince and his Man; but at his coming, finding themelves too weak, they ought that afety in their heels, which their Swords could not give them; the Prince and his Man had Jackboots on, and were unable to follow them; and the Stranger was o weary with the Blood he had lot, and the wearines of o tedious a conflict, that he had carce trength enough to keep him on his Legs; however, he ued that little he had in coming up to the Prince, and thanking him for his own Life, and his beautious Companions; the Prince told him, he owed it to his own Valour, and the favour of Heaven, which eldom fails to help the Couragious, epecially when they have Jutice on their ide:
The Prince ordering his Man to look to the trangers Wounds and bind them up, went himelf to Compliment the Lady upon her delivery:

He found her leaning on her Maid, bewailing the Death of
that Stranger who was killed before he came there, but how was he amazed, when looking in her Face he found it to be Marinda: When he firt came in to her aitance, her Hoods were over her Face; which was the Reaon he did not know her, and the Beavor of his Morion being down was the caue of the like ignorance in her; though he very little expected to meet her there, yet the joy to ee her afe, overcame his amazement, and he was about to tetifie it, with all the extaie which his Paion raied in him:

When he, cating an angry frown at him, aid, I thought, Sir, to have given my Deliverer the greatet thanks for the recuing yonder Gentleman's Life, and my Honour, from the Hands of thee wicked Villains; but ince it is to you I mut pay them; I mut at the ame time declare, that I had rather they hould have taken my Life, than, forced me to owe it to you; go, leave me to be a prey to them whom thou hat hunted away, for I had rather dye here, bemoaning this poor Gentleman who fell in the defence of my Honour, than take refuge with you, who whilt you defend it from others, endeavour to prey upon it your elf. He anwered
her very mildly, and would fain have expotulated with her concerning his Innocence, but he at over the Dead Gentleman bewailing him, and would not hearken, nor anwer one word to what he aid; the Prince having found her o kind at his lat eeing her in Clonmell, wondered trangely at this Capricio of his Fortune, and turning away from her, went to the wounded Gentleman, to ee whether he could unfold him the Riddle. He aid, all that he knew of it, was, that the Dead Gentleman was a profeed Servant to her, as he was to her Couin, and that Marinda having made a udden reolution to go for Dublin, they two proffer'd to accompany her thither; that he would not let them take as much as a Man with them, becaue he would not have any one know which way they were gone; that he had deir'd them to avoid the High-roads as much as they could, becaue he had no mind to be known by any who came from Dublin-ward; that in this by-road they met thoe Rapperees, who bade them deliver; that the Gentleman who Courted her, hot at one of them and killed him; that then they all fell upon them two,
who had no other way to defend themelves and the two Women, than by letting them go behind them, and they defend that gap, till ome others Riding that Road might come to their help; that the Gentleman was killed, as he made a pas at that econd Man who lay Dead by him, and that himelf, natching up the Dead Man's half-pike, as being a better defence than his Sword, had held them all in play till he came into his Recue. The Ladies expreing o great a reentment againt him, made the Stranger curious to know who it was; but the Servant had no ooner informed him that it was the Prince of Sâ€”g, but he begged a thouand pardons for the rudenes his ignorance made him commit; and aid, that his Highnes had acted with a Bravery uitable to his Quality; and that though he never before had the Honour to know him, yet what he had een his Highnes perform in this little acquaintance, hould make him repect him more for his Deerts, than his Title. The Prince had very little relih for all the Praies the Stranger heaped upon him, and only deired him to prevail with the
Lady, to go back to Clonmell with him. While the Prince's Man went to catch the Hores, the Stranger peruaded Marinda to return back with him; and getting all upon the Hores, they rode before, only the Prince got upon his Man's, and the Man on the Dead Gentleman's, and laying the Body before him, they Rode to the next. Town; the Gentleman's wounds were light ones, and needed little Cure, beides ret and a recruit of Blood; therefore he went with Marinda the next day to Clonmell; but the Prince's wound was large, and had lot him o much Blood, that his Life was in danger. Marinda the next day ent him a Surgeon, and a Heare, to carry the Gentleman to Clonmell, he was Buried there, and he hewed uch an exceive Grief at his Funeral, that no one who knew he Courted her, but thought that he Loved him; the Prince's being wounded came to Celadon's Ears, but he wondered that it was in recuing Marinda, whom he thought all the while to have been at home; he treight took Hore and came to the Prince, and found him very weak, wanting ret, and incapable of taking any: to hear that his Rival was
o bemoaned by Marinda, was wore than Poyon to his wounds; to have een her prefer another before his face; one who was Dead, and inenible of her Kindnees, before him, who valued them at o high a rate; and to think, that the other, who was but â€¢ private Gentleman, was preferr'd by his Mitres, before him and all his Titles, raied a Noble Indignation in him, which bepread his Face with a redder dye, than that of his Wound. When he had told Celadon her unkind Behaviour towards him; he gueed immediately what was the Reaon of it, but would not tell the Prince, for fear it hould incene him:

He only made a light matter of it, and told his Highnes that if he woold write a Line by him, for a pretence to him to ee her, he would oon accommodate the difference; and et him as much in her Favour as ever; the Prince eemed to give but little credit to thee hopes, but becaue he would leave nothing unattempted, ordering that no body hould diturb their privacy, he bade Celadon write, whilt he dictated him thee words.

body.p:
IF it be a Fault to have recued my Fair One from her Enemies; if it be a Crime unpardonable, to have pent a great part of my Blood in revenging the death of my Rival, becaue I did not lay down my Life with his, then will I offer up the poor remainder of my Blood, to atone for the Cowardie I have been Guilty of; and hall think my Life old at too dear a rate, if it hould draw o many precious Tears from your Eyes, as did that happy Gentleman, who even in his Death triumphed over the Love of his Survivor. But if I was as willing to expoe my elf for your ake, and he was the firt in your Defence, only by the good Fortune, of being with you at the beginning of the
danger; I know not why the living Servant hould not hare more of your favour than the dead one; ince he would have died as willingly at your Feet, had not your Fortune commanded him to live till he conquered your Enemies. Now he has kept his Life too long, ince it is become odious to you, and would gladly lay it down before the Face of his incened Divinity, if his weaknes would permit him to come there:
And if he has any deire at all to live, it is only o long till you let him know in what he has offended you:
This ure is the leat you can grant to one, who was once o happy in your favour; and 'tis all the atisfaction your Criminal deires, to know why you have condemned him, ince he has always been the

div.p: When Celadon got to Town, he came treight to Marinda's:
She was not to be poken with, but he met with Diana, (o was his Mitres called) and after the uual Complements pat, he asked her how he hould peak with her Couin:

No way, (aid he) there's no acces for you, becaue you come from the Prince. Why, Madam, aid he, is not Marinda, atisfied that the Prince has ufficiently hazarded his Life in her defence, but that he'll endanger it farther by her Cruelty? Cruelty! (anwered he) why what kindnes can he expect from a Virtuous Woman? Or what would the Wedded Sâ€”g with the Chate Marinda? And is that all the reaon of her Anger? (aid Celadon,) Has the poor Prince uffered all this for a word of mine? By Heaven (Madam) the Prince is ingle, and I am perwaded has as vertuous deigns on your Couin, as I have on you. If he has no more on her (anwered he) than I have on you, he would never again be at the expence of a igh for her:

For your part, I here dicharge you my acquaintance; your michievous Jet has been the caue of a great deal of Grief, both to my Couin and me, for the Gentleman's death,
the other Gentleman's weaknes, and the endangering the Prince's Life:

You have jeted fairly, you had like to have jeted the Prince at once out of his Life and Mitres, your-elf you have jeted out of my Favour, I will aure you; and o farewell good jeting, Mr. Celadon, for if I ever any more admit of your Jets, I'll give you leave to make a Jet of me as long as you live. Saying this he flung away into her Couins Room, and all that Celadon could ay, could not get either of them to peak a word to him. She told Marinda that the Prince was innocent, and, by Celadon's Confeion, had no deigns, but what were honourable and virtuous:

At the ame time the Maid came up, and brought them a Letter, which Celadon ent to Marinda, and the ame which he had written from the Prince's Mouth; the Servant told them that he was returning to the Prince, and deired to ee them before he went, that he might know what Service they had to command him. Neither of them would conent to ee one who had been the Author of their late troubles:

But Diana told her Couin that the Prince, who was innocent, ought not to uffer for him; that he
hould rather hew her elf kinder than ever, to one he had o cauelely tormented: Marinda's own Love did take his part o much, and joyn o prevalently with her Couin's Arguments, that it made her give ome mall interval to her Griefs, to pay that which was due to her Love. She wrote a Letter, and ent it to Celadon, who made what hate he could to leave an angry Mitres, to ee his wounded Prince, and cure his Body, by this overeign Ballom which he brought for his mind. The Prince (when he came before him) would not tay to tell him how he did, till he firt asked how he had ucceeded. As well for you, Sir, (aid he) as you can wih, and as ill for my elf; how ill for my elf, I will tell you hereafter; how well for your Highnes, this Letter will acquaint you. At thee words he gave him the Letter; and the Prince, with a great deal of hate, breaking it open, found thee words.

body.p:
HOw hall I be ilent, when Jutice obliges me to confes I have wronged you? Or how hall I have the face to confes
a Rudenes, which a miundertanding made me guilty of? I was too rah to condemn you without a hearing; but I hope your Highnes will pardon that rahnes, when you hall conider it was in the defence of (that which I prefer before all things) my Vertue. Through the weaknes of my Sex makes me careful of my life; yet did your Highnes need it, I could willingly expoe it as lavihly in your behalf, as you did yours in mine:
Yet my Innocence (which is dearer to me than that Life) I mut not acrifice, no, not to you. Your Highnes has more Generoity, than to begrudge a Gentleman a few Tears, who lot his Life in my defence:
They were no more than what I owed both to Gratitude and Humanity:
Neither ought you to infer from thence, that the Dead hares more of my Favour than the Living:
I would convince you of the contrary, if it were fitting:
But your Highnes's condecention mut not make me forget, that you are a Prince, and that my highet deeres rie no higher than to be the

div.p: You deerve all things, Divine Marinda, (aid the paionate Prince) what Title is too High, or Etate too Magnificent to admit you for a Partner? I will no more indulge this vain Ambition, or let it cros my Love:

Tell me, Celadon, (aid he) does not Marinda, with her natural Beauty look finer than our Proudet Court Ladies, tho' decked with all their Gaudy Cotly Drees? Yet that lovely Body is but the Shell of a more glorious Inhabitant, and is as far out-hone by that more radiant Gut, which lies within, as your choicet Jewels exceed the lutre of the Cask, which holds them:
For her Illutrious mind has got as inexhautible a tore of rare perfections in it, as the famed Potoi has of Riches:

And as in that the greedy Spanih Conquerour, the farther he diggs, finds till more new upplies of Ore; o whoever makes himelf Mater of her richer Heart, will till dicover there new Mines of Radiant Vertues, o infinite they are, that they would tire the mot inquiitive Lover to find them all, and each of them has uch peculiar Charms in't, enough to make him leave his crutiny after more, to admire that one which his firt earch does find. Ah, Sir, (aid Celadon, now your Highnes is happy and in favour, you do not
conider him who is clearly cat off by his Mitres, for what he did only with deign to erve you; for it was my telling Diana that your Highnes was married, and confeing the falhood afterward, has o put me out of her favour, that he has forbidden me ever eeing her again. Tho' (aid the Prince) that was an unlucky Policy of yours, yet ince 'twas well deigned, you hall not uffer for it, and therefore take my word, that the ame day which makes me happy, hall make you o to; and as our Loves are joyn'd, o hall our Fortunes. Your Highnes (aid Celadon) cannot be more in Love with the perfections of your Mitres, than eem with the Wit and good Humour of mine:

Beides, her Baggs which are o large and tempting, it would grieve my heart to part with them, after I was in o fair a way for obtaining her. The Prince anwered, that both their Loves waited only for his Health, and then he would oon ee them conumated. He wrote two or three Letters more to Marinda whilt he lay ill, but the Reader mut excue me, if I produce them not here, ince Marinda burned them to prevent a dicovery; and Secretary Celadon was not o careful to keep any Copies. Now had the active Sun run through our Celetial ign, and his pale
Siter gone through her Monthly coure, and changed her Orb, whilt the poor Prince kept his Bed, and with the los of Blood had been as pale as he; at length the help of Art retored his Health, trengthning Nature began to exert her power, and tho' he was not rien of a udden to her former vigour, yet he made great advances, and every day perceived her trength encreaing:
His impatient Love would tay no longer than till he was able to travel, and then it carried him back to Clonmell, to ee his long abent Mitres:

He rode to his Lodgings at Marinda's Mothers, but hearing Muick in the Houe, and the Mirth of Company within, he asked what was the Matter. 'Tis, (aid one) a preparation for Madam Diana's Wedding, who is jut now to be Married. Married! aid Celadon, O that I had either come ooner or later; for my Honour ake I cannot ee my Mitres Married away before my Face, and yet I am come too late to prevent it; but what can be done on uch a udden I'll do. Saying this, he alighted, and ruhed into the Houe, and the Prince followed him in to ee what his deign was. Celadon entered jut as the Ceremony began, and with a threatning voice cryed, I forbid the Banes; and if the intended Bridegroom will
defer his hopes o long, to go aide with me, I will convince him, that my Title to her is better than his. The Company wonder'd to ee this Challenge laid to her; her Relations, who were by, expected her to peak; but he was prevented by the Bridgeroom, who fiercely cryed, that it belonged to none but him, to vindicate his Title to her:

Some Officers were there, the Bridgerooms Friends, and would have taken up his quarrel, but forbore out of repect to the Prince, expecting what he would do in it. The Prince knowing the Gentleman to be the ame whom he had een Combat with o many Enemies, to ave Marinda, had uch an opinion of his Valour, that the would fain have decided the Quarrel, without injuring either of the Pretenders:

Had he been at his dipoal, Celadon hould have had her, if at her Parents, they had decided it for the Spaniard: Therefore he thought it bet to leave it to her elf, and therefore poke to this purpoe.
Gentlemen, I have uch an eteem for you both, that I would not have you fight, ince, which ever falls, the Law will lay hold on the other, and o in triving which hall have the Lady, both of you will loe her; if you will tand to my advice, let it be thus. Refer your Caue to the Lady, and give her three days time to conider
of it, in which time let both of you have free acces to make your Court to her, and at the three days end, let her take which he will:
If, Celadon, her choice does decide it againt you, you mut ubmit; but if he like you bet, there is no reaon why your taying with me in my illnes, hould make you loe your Mitres. The Gentleman aid, that, ince he owed his Life to the Prince's Valour, he would not deny him this; and Celadon was glad to win o much to try his Fortune in. While the three days lated, the two Suiters took their turns to Court Diana: On the fourth day, the Muick play'd again, the Priet was preent, and the admiring Company tood in upence, to ee who was the detined Bridegroom. The Bride tood out, and in making her Choice, pake thus:
You are here come together, my Relations, and good Acquaintance, to et me Married, and I am happy in having the choice of two Gentleman, the refued of which may, if his deerts are anwered, have many a better proffer; however, if they were ever o good, one of them mut be rejected, therefore I would not have the diappointed one take it ill that I refue him. One of them has been longer my Servant, but the other was more zealous while he was o:
The Spaniard has been the more Complaiant, but the Englihman
the Fonder:
The Spaniard the truer Courtier, but the Englihman the truer Lover; therefore, as commonly Love is oonet raied in one Breat, by eeing it firt in the other, o the Englihman has the advantage of the Spaniard, and my heart catched that Paion, as it were by Contagion from his:
Yet, on the other ide, I hould not forget my Duty; my Father takes the Spaniard's part, well, but Love takes the Englihman's:
Then I mut beg my Father's pardon, if I leave the Spaniard to receive his reward from him whom he courted, and deire the Company to judge, if I ought not rather to yield him my Love, who ued to me for it, than to him who Courted my Parents. The Company was divided in their opinions, as their Acquaintance byaed them; and ome murmured as the Incontancy of her Humour, whilt others applauded her Choice. Celadon ran to give her thanks, with all the kindet expreions his Joy could inpire him with; and his Rival, ditracted with Grief and Shame at his unexpected repule, tood uncertain on that udden Emergency, how to behave himelf:

He was awaked out of this Trance, by a Gentlewoman, who came to him, and aid, Take heart, Seignior, be not ahamed of a Denial, which not your want of Merit, but my Contrivance was the occaion of;
'twas I that peruaded the Lady to refue you, and I trut you will pardon me, when I ay it was for my own ake that I did it. Without quetion the Company thought this an odd ort of Confidence, for a Gentlewoman to Court a Man, in o kind terms, and o publickly too:

Her Garb was very fine, her Shape and Air gentile, and her Face, which was one of the mot amiable ones there, pake her to be in the prime of her years; yet neither her Dres, Youth, Beauty, or Love, could prevail the leat on our dicontented Spaniard, who would not once vouchafe to look on her. What then, (aid he) is my Contancy thus requited? Or can two years time caue o much alteration, as to make Atolfo forget me? Thee words made the Spaniard turn towards her, and he no ooner aw her Face, but he cry'd out, am I in a Dream? Or do I truly behold once again, the Face of my beloved Faniaca? Now, Celadon, I yield thee up thy Mitres, and quit all my pretenions to her, for this which I have newly found. Celadon gladly thanked him for his ubmiion to Diana's Choice, and all the Company bore a part with the Spaniard in the Joy he conceived at the change of his Mitres:

But the beautiful Indian, who longed to hear how
he came for Ireland, aid, It is now, my Atolfo, two years ince you and I parted, wonder not then if I am deirous to know what befell you ince that, and how you ecaped a Death which o apparently threatned you; my endeavours to find you out here, made me relate all the paages of our Acquaintance hitherto, and therefore I believe there is no accident in the remaining part of your Life, which is too ecret for the Ears of this honourable Company:

I have had none, (aid he) which I will not freely tell, but to the undertanding my Relation, it is requiite that this Illutrious Company hould know ome things, which for want of opportunity, have as yet been a ecret to you, as well as to them. My Father is a Gentleman of a plentiful Etate near Sevill, by my Mothers death he was left a Widdower with two Children, Me and a Daughter, both which he was very fond of, as being his only Comforts, the Relicts of his deceaed Wife, and the Pledges of his youthful Love:

There lived near us an old Couple who had the like number of Children, a Son and a Daughter, they were intimate Friends of my Father's, and o free with us, that notwithtanding the evere retraints of our Countrey upon young Perons, yet
our Families oberved no uch Cutom, but we young ones convered with one another with the ame freedom as if we had been near Relations:

And as youthful familiarity in different Sexes, uually ends in Love, o it proved with us, for our Neighbour's Son and my Siter had uch a mutual Affection, that they were never well but in one anothers Company; and his Siter, whether by her own inclination, or their etting on, eemed as uneaie unles when he was in mine; had he been handome, perhaps I hould have taken as much diverion in his Siter's Company, as he did in mine; but I thought thoe Complements thrown away, which were betowed on an ugly Face; nor could my Wit help me with one fond Vow or happy Expreion, for want of Beauty to inpire it; This made me avoid her Company to get into his; but when I aw him hun mine as much, and that he and my Siter coveted to be always together; his growing more reerved to me than formerly, and ome ymptoms which I perceived in my Siter; her frequent ighs at parting, her bluhes at meeting him, and ome other lips, which the mot diembling of your Sex find difficult to hide, gave me apparent caue to think that he loved him.
He and I were once as great as 2 Brothers laid our Breats open to one another thence his never dicovering the leat to me, concerning his paion for my Siter, made his Love look to me, as if it deigned nothing that was honet. I had then to wait on me a Turkih Captive, who was taken away young, and having been bred up everal years in my Father's Houe, was very truty and dicreet; I let no one know my upitions, but him, and ordered him to be a Spy on all my Siter's Actions; and if ever he oberved any thing remarkable between them two, that he would acquaint me with it:

He oberved my Commands, and one time brought me word, that he had over-heard him and my Siter dicouring; that he deired him to ask her of my Father, and that very oon, or he hould be dicovered to be with Child, and o be digraced, and turned out of Doors; tho' this was but what I feared to find out, yet now I found thoe fears true, it enraged me both againt him and my Siter:

However, the conideration of her Sex's weaknes (which is an unequal Combatant for Love, when aited by earnetnes and opportunity) made me pardon her o far, as to leave her to be punihed by the ill conequences of her own Folly; but him I reolved
to be revenged on:

Tho' my blood boyled at the firt ight of him, yet I diembled my anger in publick, and told him that I had omething to impart to him, if he would take a walk with me into the Fields in the cool of the Evening; he conented, and we went out together; at we walked on talking, I drew him inenibly to a private place, and then retiring a little ditance from him, I bade him draw:
Sure you are in jet (aid he) you will not draw that Sword againt your Friend, which you have before now drawn in my defence:
This Sword (aid I) was drawn then for my Friend, but now againt the wort of mine Enemies, one who has abued my Friendhip, and my Siter's Love:
Yet thus much I will give to our former Affection, Marry her, and alve up the Injury thou hat done her, and I will forgive thee mine:

What, (aid he) and are you turned a Bravo to hector me into Marriage? Know then that I will never do it, neither hall it ever be aid, that Guzman valued his Honour o little, as to make a Wife of his Whore. Whore! (aid I) that word I will engrave on thy traiterous Heart; at thee words he leapt back and drew, I made at him with a great deal of Fury; but being appeaed by ome Blood I drew
from him, I proffered him again the ame conditions of Reconciliation; but his Rage made him deaf to Reaon:
We fought on, till one thrut I made at his Breat ended our difference, by his fall:

I fled in all hate to the Sea-ide, where by good chance there was a Ship under Sail bound for the Indies; I went aboard her; Landed in America amongt ome Souldiers, who were ent to re-inforce our Country Garrions there:
I was a private Souldier, till a Fight that I ignalized my elf in, raied me to a Captain's Commiion; 'twas in this tation I was, when I came acquainted with you:
You know the Captain of the Man of War, which boarded us, ent me Prioner to Sevill, with my other Countrymen:
Near this Town my Father lived; I ent him word of my being in Prion, and he treight came to ee me, but told me, he mut not own me for his Son, let it hould cot me my Life:

He applauded my revenging the dihonour done to my Family; but aid, that there had been Warrants iued out againt me, and 500 Duckats, by the deceaed's Friends, promied him that hould eize me; that if I hould tand a Tryal, and ecape the Law, yet their private revenge would reach me; therefore, he aid he would make Friends for me and
my fellow Prioners, that we hould be dimied, and then he would have me pend ome years abroad, and when Time, or Death had cured the malice of my Enemies, he would get my pardon, and call me home. I took his advice, and as oon as I was freed, hearing that the Hollanders were raiing Souldiers, for ome deign they had not yet divulged, I entered Volunteer into that Party which came for England; you have all heard how we ucceeded, and that intead of a Battel, we came as it were to a Triumph; for the Englih came over to our ide; thence we took Shipping for Ireland, and in Dublin I received a upply from my Father, which bought me the Command of a Troop; I was at the Boyn near Schomberg when he was killed; I lay in the Camp before Limerick, and took my chance of War, among thoe Brave Men that fell in the Trenches; I Quarrelled with the Prince t'other Night, mitaking him for ome Rival that Serenaded Diana; but the Guards coming up, and my finding out my Errour, delivered me from his Sword too:

I was afterwards engaged with ten Irih at once, and fortunately recued by the Prince's Valour; o that my kind Stars preerved me through all thee dangers, to fall the econd time a Victim
to your Eyes, my former Conquerours; I Courted I confes that Lady, but it was, becaue I aw not the leat likelihood, of ever finding my Beloved Faniaca; and therefore, I thought her Fortune would prove a good helter for a Punihed Man, who had been toed from Spain to the Indies, from the Indies to Spain, from Spain to England, from England hither, and one, that durit not et foot again on his Native Country:

Beides her Wit and good Humour, placed her much in my Eteem, though all thoe Perfections vanih in any Woman, when you my incomparable Mitres are by. Thus the Spaniard ended his Relation, and the Company with no little pleaure, reflected on the alterations of Fortune; which, after toing them o far aunder, by the contrary guts of Adverity, now by one properous Gale, brought them together to their deired Harbour:

The two Happy Couple, would willingly have prevented all future dangers, by fatning that indioluble Knot, which nothing but Death can untye, but Marinda deired, her Couin, to forbear hers for two or three days; and the Fair Indian deired her Spaniard, to defer their Joys o long, it not being fit, that he hould be admitted to o Solemn a Ceremony
of the Church, as that of Matrimony, till he were firt lited among the number of her Children:
The Priet who came there no Celebrate their Marriage, performed this Solemnity, and all the Company wihed the Fair Convert Joy:

Mirth and Feating took up the ret of the day, and made up an intire Friendhip, between the Brisk Celadon, and the Valiant Spaniard, who now Quarrelled no longer for a Mitres. But if ome good natured Reader hould be too much concerned for the Amorous Prince, whoe Intrigue eems to have tood till, whilt the others have run almot to the end of their Race; let him know, that his went the ame pace with theirs; though the Author, to comply with Marinda's Modety, brought her not o openly acting the Lover's part, as he did the brisk Diana, or the bolder Indian; for as the main wheel of a Clock, though it turns all the ret, yet goes it elf with uch an inenible motion, that to an unskilful Eye it eems to tand till; o the Prince's and Marinda's Amour, was carried on indicernably to others, and eem'd to them to be at a tand, whilt indeed it was the chief mover of the two other Intrigues, and pointed out to them the long wihed for,
the Matrimonial Hour:

You mut therefore undertand, that after all the dark unuccesful days which our Prince had ighed away, in doubtful Hopes, ditracting Fears, and his lat black ones of Depair; Fortune vindicated her old Title of Incontancy, in being kind to him again, in bringing him that propitious critical minute, in which they ay, the Coyet Lady (if you nick the right time) is to be won:
The Prince exactly hit it in the firt Viit he made Marinda; as oon as the deigned Marriage was deferred, and the Company gone, he went to pay his particular Repects to the Lady of his Vows:

He found her in the Garden with her Couin, dicouring about the unexpected breaking off her Marriage, and Celadon according to his priviledge, taking her into an Ally aide, left the Prince in another, with Marinda; and what time they had there together, he improved to the utmot, in hewing her how incerely he had been her Servant, from the firt ight he ever had of her, till then; and told her, what he required of her in retaliation, and upon what Honourable Conditions he expected it; he anwered with all the kindnes due to o fond a Lover, and with a mixture of that ubmiive
Civility, which he paid him as he was a Prince, tho' one who profeed himelf her Servant; and that his Highnes might not cenure her to have beep either Rude or Cruel in her Behaviour towards him, through the whole coure of their Acquaintance; he deired, that he would hear thoe things from her Couin's Mouth, which he thought not o fit for her own; Diana was called for, and Marinda deiring her to acquaint the Prince with all he knew of her Thoughts, without diguiing any thing; he Dicoured with Celadon apart, while her Couin began thus to the Prince, who was more than ordinarily attentive. When my Couin ordered me to tell you her greatet; privacies, thoe of her Love; he did but give the Reins to that paion, which has alwaies been too trong for her, ince firt the Graces your Highnes is mater of, reduced her to the condition of a Lover; and I quetion not, but he has had undeniable proofs of an equal Affection in you; or ele, (by what I know of her Humour) he would rather have Died, than once uffered it to be known; your Highnes over-hearing our Dicoure at the Well, opened a light to the dicovery of that Affection, which otherwie had been
doom'd to perpetual obcurity; for though your Highnes, did make ome Addrees to her, which as he told me, erved to ruin her the more, yet they would never have proved any advantage to you; ince we both thought, that you poke out of Raillery more than any erious deign; beides in the highet tide of her Paion, he profeed, he would rather uffer any thing than own it to you; the firt Night your Highnes Serenaded her, he hewed o little concern at it, till you were gone, that I thought it had been a Frolick of the Spaniard's Gallantry, who about that time came acquainted with me, 'twas I poke to you out of the window, though when the difference of Voice dicovered my mitake, I broke off the parly; that time the Indian came to Town, and lighting firt into my Couin's Acquaintance, he told her the Dream he had about you; I will not tell it over again, becaue your Highnes has heard it already, only in vindication of the Indian's Skill, let me aure your Highnes, that he told my Couin, he hould have the Gentleman he Dreamed of; he interpreted the little Archer, who was on your ide, to be Love, the Giant on hers, Honour; that Honour's going over
to your ide, and leaving her defenceles, ignified, that your proffering to Marry her, would overcome her obtinacy; and the Cupid's hooting her through, is eaie enough to be left to your Highnes's Explanation; the Indian promiing her ucces, made her indulge that Love, which he bridled before, and brought her abroad to the Ball: Marinda, Madam, was nor at the lat Ball, aid the Prince: Yes, Sir, aid Diana, if your Highnes remembers, there were two in Spanih Dres, the one was the Indian, the other Marinda; but ure, aid the Prince, Marinda was not not with her in my Room the next day:

She was with your Highnes both times, aid Diana; nay, it was he whoe Advice you asked in the Cloet; he came home that Night, with all the marks of a violent Grief, at omething which your Highnes had aid to her, and reolved withall, never to ee, hear, or peak to you more; when he repreented the Fortune-Teller, he forbad your Highnes to proecute the Intrigue any farther, unles you deigned to carry it on Honourably; and your going on with it, by giving her your Company o often afterwards, and the Indians
<> averring that he was detined for you,
made her believe, your Highnes had altered your mind for the better; as you know, Lovers above all People are aptet to believe things will come to pas fortunately, meerly becaue they would have it o; this her belief was trengthned by the kind promiing Letter you ent her from Limerick; which Letter, induced me too, to think that your Highnes had deigned omething to her advantage:

You aw what a free reception he gave you, at your return from the Camp, till Celadon's telling me that you were Married, dahed all the Joy I conceived at the properity of her Amour, and was very near breaking her Heart, in endeavouring to gain a Conquet over her Love; but when he found how difficult that was, he aid, he would punih your illegal Paion, and her own at the ame time; and let a fit of Love hould make her recant, he put it in Execution immediately; there was a Gentleman of a coniderable Fortune, who had een her at my Father's in Dublin, and fallen in Love with her; this Gentleman being then come to Clonmell to ee her, he deired him to wait on her to Dublin, and I deired my Servant the Spaniard, that he would accompany her thither; he told me, that he would rather Marry him whom he did
not Love, than give a longer encouragement to any unlawful Affection, which your Highnes might entertain for her; that would have bereaved you of her for ever, had not he been met by thoe Rapperees; her Servant fell there, and though he was mightily concerned for your Highnes's danger, yet her Vertue drew thoe Tears from her, which he thought due to her Defender's Misfortune; and might erve to make you depair, ever coming into her favour again:

But when Celadon undeceived us, by telling me that your being Married, was only an invention of his own, Shame and Love returned very powerfully upon her; Shame, that he had ued you o ill without a caue; and that Love, which before was only uppret by her Reentments, flourihed now with greater vigour than before; This dicovery which regained your Highnes her Affection, lot Celadon mine; and my Anger at his crafty deceit, and his being the caue of o much bloodhed, (though innocently) made me reolve on the ame way to get rid of him, which my Couin deigned againt you, that is, by Marrying another; and the Spanih Gentleman, who had my Father's Conent, coming then wounded from a Journey which he undertook
to erve me; I thought once to reward his Service, and punih Celadon's Falenes, and imagined I might do it with les diturbance, whilt your indipoition kept him out of the way; but Fate, which they ay preides over our Marriages, as well as our Deaths, ordered it otherwie, and brought him jut time enough to upend it. The Prince gave the mot ample demontrations of Joy, at the etlednes which this Relation hew'd to be in Marinda's Love; and having thank'd the Ingenious Diana for the comfort he had given him, he walked towards the other Couple; they joyned Company, and the Prince deired Marinda that he would compleat his Happines, by etting Celadon as high in his Mitres's Favour, as himelf was in hers:

The Beautiful Marinda granted him this requet, as the firt demontration of her Obedience; he endeavoured it o effectually, that preently he made her Couin pardon Celadon's former micarriage, and receive him again into her favour; neither did Marinda find it any thing difficult to peruade her to this; for of all People, Mitrees are the mot forgiving, indulgent Perons to thoe they Love; and let them diemble it as much as they pleae, they
cannot be long Angry at any fault a Lover commits, unles it eem to proceed from want of Affection; but Celadon not being of that Nature, was oon forgiven, and as a proof of it, was encouraged to hope he would Vote for him:

The next morning, the Indian came to wait on the two Couins, and told Diana, that he who was in Election to be her Husband, was the Spaniard whom he had been o long looking for; Marinda had invited her to the Wedding, and he came in a little after the Prince had deferr'd it, and then eeing it put off, would not dicover her elf to the Spaniard; he deired Diana to keep him till in ignorance, that when he was refued, he might ee how he would excue himelf to her: Diana deired no les than he, that it might be kept ecret, let Celadon hould eteem her love the les, thinking that the Spaniard being owned by another, made her take him for a hift; this was the reult of the three days Tryal, and hence it came to pas, that the Spaniard dejected at the los of one Mitres, was elevated by the unexpected finding out another, whom he Loved better:

The hort prorogation of their Marriages, only continued till the Prince had prepared for his; at lat
the expected day came, and rewarded the three longing Lovers with the intire poeion of their Mitrees:

The Beautiful Marinda, the Ingenious Diana, and the Pritty Faniaca, ubmitted themelves to the power of their Youthful Conquerours. Diana had all the felicity he could wih, in having him he Loved; the Indian gained not only her dear Spaniard, but a Fortune with him, for he that day received News from his Father, that his old Enemy was Dead, his Pardon taken out, and with it, he had orders to come home, and take poeion of an Etate his Father gave him; the Beautiful Marinda received the reward of her invincible Vertue, in Loving and being Beloved, and in having gained a Prince, who raied her Quality as high (in comparion of what he was before) as a Woman's Ambition could deire; thee were the Pleaures of the Wedding Day, heightned by the addition of Muick, Feating, and Mirth; but the Night came, we mut like their Bride Maids, conduct them to their Beds, and drawing the Curtains leave them there, to the full Enjoyment of thoe Pleaures, whoe Raptures, none but Experienced Lovers know, and the Contant ones may expect to attain.
